  11. I've used mach razors by gilette since college because I thought that was the only option. Then I found these razor blades and handles! It takes a while to get used to shaving, as it's curved vs, mach blades are at the perfect angle for easy shaving. 2nd, it takes a couple of passes since there's only 1 blade, vs mach 3's that have 3 blades in series. I wish theres a handle that you can insert 2 or 3 blades in series. But overall, I don't grow too much facial hair and this thing works as well as a cheap bic disposable. So it's great economical item and looks better and handles better than the disposables.
  12. I purchased this item as a second razor. It doesn't give you a good shave. Putting in and taking out the blade is awkward. I never use it.
  13. Decent product. Works fine and delivers a good shave. Plus it's easy to clean and maintain.
  14. face cuts when shaving
  15. I bought this as a gift for my father and he loved it. I'm very pleased with it.
  16. First of all it took two months to arrive. When I opened the package I was shocked. This thing is so cheaply made! It is made of crude paper-thin pot metal. It is not stainless steel nor is it chrome plated. It's just regular steel, and it rusts! It doesnt even look like the one in the picture. Apparently depending on the vendor that sends you this item, there is a good version and a bad version. Don't take the risk! You'll likely get the bad version like me. Another point I should make is that the blade exposure is terribly dangerous and wrongly angled. After installing the blade, the blade actually bends along the cutting edge like waves! And on top of that, the blade is angled wrong so that it is very painful when shaving. This thing is a piece of junk and I don't want anyone else to get ripped off. I know this razor is cheap, and I purchased it as a backup razor and to leave in my locker at my club. But it should at least function properly! I wasn't expecting the best shave like my Edwin Jagger razor gives me, but come on! This thing is useless! I shaved once with it, it tore my face up and left me bleeding everywhere due to the wrong angle, bends, and blade exposure. Needless to say it went into my garbage can that day. Do yourself a huge favor and pay 20 - 30 dollars for a decent safety razor. I have been wet shaving with safety razors all my life so take my advice!
  17. bought it for my husband and he loves its, he's used electric and the disposables but prefers a double edge razor
  18. I have used many different shaving products from the &#34;Magic Shave Shaving Powder Depilatory&#34; to my $200 &#34;Braun Series 5-550cc&#34;. After many razor bumps, experience, and even more money spent on shaving products, I ran into this. From a price to quality ratio, it is hands down one of the greatest shavers out there. I'll be the first to admit that I am a shaving snob, having spent countless hours in the Art of Shaving store in my local mall, even still, the pure simplicity of this product keeps me reaching only for it every morning in my Dopp Kit. It takes a couple shaves to get the shaving angle precise, but I cannot praise this little razor enough. A few things to keep in mind is that if your purchase is time sensitive, then you might want to buy from the seller listed within the U.S. Also, I find this product to work well with the Remington King of Shaves Alpha gel. One more thing worth mentioning that another reviewer touched upon is that the included razor blade does not last long. However, the Wilkinson sword classic double edge razor blades work like a dream. I brought a pack from my local store and I did not know what I was missing. I suggest buying this along with some quality blades. For individuals who travel, especially to less developed countries, blades are very easy to source, which makes this my perfect travel companion. Overall, this product is definitely worth a try, I plan on buying a couple more just in case.
  19. Great, simple razor. I'm new to the DE shaving scene, and this is my second razor. It took a long time to get to me, but was still delivered before the expected date. The handle is the perfect length, bar comb is closed (safer for noobs), and blades fit perfectly. Overall, a great razor for DE shaving.

  26. I loved shaving with this razor for the couple months it worked. It's an awesome intro into safety razor shaving, but if you really enjoy shaving with it pick up a better one. I ended up just going to the antique store and buying a short handled Gillette and a really nice Schick for $10 each. If you want to get into, or used to, shaving with a safety razor this is a good start.<br /><br />Things to keep in mind when starting: Get a better quality shave soap and a badger brush. Invest in a razor stand (to help maintain the brush). Clean the razor after every shave and the blades will last longer. You can get razor blades at the local store much cheaper than online (less than $2 for ten blades at wally world). While Wilkensen Sword may be duller than [insert super sharp blade here], they work much better for beginners and don't butcher your face.<br /><br />I've loved switching to a safety razor and I've gotten much closer shaves with it than my cheapo Bic 2-blade things. Do your research on wet shaving and you will look forward to shaving every day instead of dreading it. One awesome thing about these razors is that they are super easy to clean. Unscrew the top, rinse, sometimes scrub, and done.

I highly recommend a good old fashioned shave soap *I use Williams Mug type* not cream . Over all I would highly recommend this product.

  40. I tried this item for several weeks and ended up tossing it out in favor of the Feather Double Edge Safety Razor (which costs around $15 through Amazon). This shaver is crudely made and the heavy pot-steel handle makes it awkwardly balanced.<br /><br />Loading the shaver requires that you unscrew the handle to remove the blade head, remove the old blade, carefully insert a new blade, and reassemble the entire shebang. In contrast, the Feather is a much more precision-made and user-friendly item--you merely twist the knurled knob under the shave head and the head pops open like a clamshell to allow you to exchange the blades.<br /><br />I noticed after a few weeks that the metal coating on the head was wearing out and the item was beginning to show spots of rust.<br /><br />All in all, it was a waste of money. My advice is to invest a little more in a well-made shaver (like the Feather or the Merkur) that you'll be able to use for years.

  61. I bought this to start learning how to shave with a safety razor. I cut myself all up the first week, but I finally started to figure it out. I had a feeling the razor was making it more difficult than it should have been to get the right angle, though, because even with more muscle control and experience, I was still getting cut.<br /><br />I finally shelled out the money for a Edwin Jagger De89lbl, and the difference is night and day. It holds the blade at the precise right angle to your face every time, with a shape around the blade that prevents it from cutting at all when at the wrong angle. Which means, unlike this one where if you hold it wrong it WILL cut you up, instead you are either holding it properly and getting a good shave, or rubbing the razor's outer edges on your face, no harm done.<br /><br />If you plan on actually shaving with a DE blade safety razor, spend the additional money on a higher end razor with the actual \\"safety\\" part of the safety razor. The truth is in this photo: http://www.amazon.com/gp/customer-media/product-gallery/B002RBF1PO/ref=cm_ciu_pdp_images_0?ie=UTF8&index=0<br /><br />[[ASIN:B002RBF1PO Edwin Jagger De89lbl Double Edge Safety Razor Chrome Plated Lined Detail, Chrome]]

  78. I ordered these a while back--the exact razor shown in the photo sold as the SODIAL and you can see my review of my product there.[[ASIN:B00A7239EK SODIAL- Silver Tone Double Edge Blade Razor Shaver w Nonslip Metal Handle]] That razor is very nice in comparison, and can be seen for sale here on Amazon under a number of different manufacturer's names for up to $25.<br /><br />This, though the photo is the same, is not at all the same. It is made to a much, much lower standard. In normal USA pricing, I would say the SODIAL that I got compares easily with a $30 to $50 German-made razor with a couple of flaws that the German one will not have. This razor, though, even at Wal-Mart, you probably wouldn't pay $5 for.<br /><br />The finish seems to only be cheap zinc. It's sort of dull and uneven, like a dipped finish--almost like a zinc-dipped nail. The handle is made of turned bar stock and there is no evidence of the rough cut piece being polished afterwards, so it has tons of scores all around--kind of looks like if you sanded it once with very, very rough sandpaper.<br /><br />It doesn't look nice. The SODIAL one, looks like the one in this photo: shiny, evenly plated, pleasant looking. When I get the chance I will take side-by-side photos that shows people what they are getting.<br /><br />The one star is earned because shipping was very fast. My SODIALs took months to get to me, but within the estimated shipping time (like the last day) that was months in advance, so I can't really complain.<br /><br />So, if the SODIAL link is still shipping the nice razor pictured, for another dollar and some wait time, you'll get a razor that looks nice and displays well, plus shaves nicely.<br /><br />I know some people will find my review unhelpful because this is such a cheap item--but it's still not what's pictured and what you get isn't better than what's in the photo--it's worse. What do you want for $2? I don't know, but if you want what's in the photo for $2.22go for the SODIAL.<br /><br />That said, this razor shaves just fine. Doesn't feel as nice as the SODIAL (but it's the same brand--ma wei or something) It suffers the same problem where loading can be a bit treacherous since the cover is short on the ends and about two to three millimeters of the ends of the razor blade are all you have to grip in order to spin the head to open it.<br /><br />Perhaps it's not fair to compare anything that's available so cheaply to my Merkur 1904/1906, I do believe that wet shavers should know that if they're going to base their first impressions on wet shaving on a razor like this, just know that for $30, you can get a razor that is so much better than either of these in terms of looks and comfort, that it might be better to just go for the Merkur. On the other hand, I got some negative comments in my review of the SODIAL because I complained about the ends of the blades sticking out. People criticized me because they had no trouble with that issue.<br /><br />Sure, I get it. It's a cheap razor and I shouldn't complain, and, well I don't think I am. I'm just letting people know what they're in for. Both this and the SODIAL could have been made with a longer blade cover like the one on the Merkur, which would have made them safer and certainly, a lot more comfortable to use, and not cost any more to produce. When the SODIAL is being sold for up to $25 as I've seen, I think it's more of a legitimate complaint.<br /><br />It's not about price--it's about the design, no matter what it costs. It's a little hairy to load it compared to most other designs--that's all.<br /><br />I bought mine purely out of curiosity, but if I were going to recommend something to get started wet shaving with, I wouldn't recommend these, but especially this one because, also, as compared to the SODIAL, the tolerance of the fit of the head is a bit sloppy. An experienced shaver can see the problem right away and be sure to put it together carefully.There's too much play in the pin locators so the head won't necessarily be parallel with the razor's edge unless you make sure that you tighten it so that it is. This is not a problem with my SODIAL.
  79. The handle of mine is metal, not plastic. It feels well made and has a nice weight to it.<br />Adding a blade is very fast and simple. I was skeptical of this razor at first but I am very<br />pleased with it. Very close shave at a very cheap price.<br /> I gave 5 stars because you cannot beat it for the price.<br /><br /> I'd recommend this to anyone who wants to switch to a more old fashioned razor. I DO have a pretty thick beard, and maybe that's the difference. I would recommend saving a few dollars more and purchase a nice Merkur or Edwin Jagger.   83. I almost never give a 1 star rating and I'm not a &#34;hater&#34; but there was just no option here.<br /><br />It took a month to receive. I didn't realize the long time shipping time until after the purchase but on with the gripes.<br /><br />It is poorly made:<br />The threaded head & handle part don’t go together very smoothly.<br /><br />The blade alignment pins in the cap don’t center the blade so one blade edge sticks out farther than on the other side.<br /><br />The base or frame doesn’t mesh with the cap squarely so the blade is presented to your face with one end of the blade much closer then the other end.<br /><br />The blade sticks out of the frame on the short ends making it uncomfortable to hold during assembly.<br /><br />I did attempt to shave with the razor using Barbasol and finished the job with only one minor nick. Not bad for the first timer using a DE razor I suppose. However . . .<br /><br />I don’t get it. They nearly have it right and for only $2. What would it cost to do it right? $3 ?<br /><br />With all that said, after cleaning up my face and letting it dry I found I had some serious stubble left all over the place so I re-shaved using my Norelco 810 and got the smooth shave I was looking for.<br /><br />If you are determined to try a DE razor please spend enough money to get one that is made of better quality parts. The razor I received was very poorly made.
  84. Sure it's not the best safety razor you can get, but for only a few dollars I think it is 5 stars considering the cost. The weight is decent. It's not a \\"heavy weight\\" by some standards but it is metal and has a solid feel to it. The handle has some nicks on it but nothing notable unless looking closely at it. The shave is very good quality. It is my first safety razor and gets a closer shave than my Fusion or Quatro. It is a great intro until I know what I want to really invest in as far as weight, handle length, and head aggressiveness. There are just so many variables and it's a good starter to find out what to look for in future purchases. The included blade is not that good though. Make sure to order some better ones when you order the razor, as the shave I got after changing the blade was FAR better.
  85. I am pleasantly surprised by the quality of the razor, it appears that the razor is made of brass or perhaps with a cooper/bronze with a nice chrome finish. The chrome is very well done, I have used the razor for over a month with no complaints. Replacing blades is easy by the 3 piece construction. I would recommend this razor to anyone wanting to get into the single blade dual edge wet shaving. I will not go back to the multi-blade nonsense with the cost and terrible shave. This razor gives excellent shaves, it isn't too aggressive or too mild it feels just right. I have used Wilkinson and Derby blades in the razor, Derby works the best for me. I plan on trying some other blades to see which one works best for my face/skin. The cost of blades are so low it doesn't cost an arm-n-leg...so it will be interesting. If you want to really get a fantastic shave use Shave Secret shaving oil you will not regret it.
  86. excellent value at any price, but to get away from $30.00 razor blade refills this is excellent. Well chromed and easy to use. I have had mine for about 6 weeks now and have not had a single cut or nick from using this razor. The one blade that is enclosed in the package with this razor is not as sharp as other blades, and should not be used at all. Go ahead and buy quality blades for this razor and you will be well satisfied.
  87. I ordered this shaver because I had never used one and this type of shaver has been around forever and it had good reviews. Well I opened the package and it felt cheap. Little over $2 I wasn't expecting much. I put the shaver in the medicine cabinet about a foot and a half above the sink. The next day I opened the cabinet door and the shaver felt out into the sink. The blade latch had come loose so I figure it was a simple click back in. As it clicked back in the handle broke in half where you twist in order to load the blade in. I never actually was able to use it because a 1 foot drop will utterly destroy this thing rendering it useless.
  88. I got mine from Imports247. It took a month to arrive but arrive it did. Since I got it, I have only been shaving using my Silver Tone razor. It is metal.   89. Like other have stated do not let the price of this razor fool you. When you recieve it it does come with one blade ( i used and had no problem with it ) and the writing on the package is clearly from overseas. The feel of the razor is heavy and you can tell of quality, not some plastic with stainless steel paint on it. I will never go back to cartirdge type razors. When i used this razor with Geo Trumper Shaving Cream it almost as if i wasent even shaving and the razor wasent doing anything. It glides across your face like its not even working. But man does it get the closest shave. No nics and pulls at my hair either. Money saver and your face will also love you forever.
  90. Smooth shave, no bumps or brusing. Ridiculously amazing price and just so very simple, I'll never go back to Gillette again.
  91. It's a pretty decent little razor, a little too light for my taste but still a good razor. For this price it's a steal, be sure to get a blade sampler pack with it if you're just starting wet shaving though.
  92. It don't give a close enough shave and it doesn't open with butterfly twist. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone who shaves everyday, don't give clean shave as expected. But for the price I guess you get what you pay for.
  93. Don't waste your money.
  94. Worked acceptably for around 18 months, then fell apart. I don't know how. It's like the threads on the head are suddenly too small to seat in the handle. Replaced with the $30ish merkur one, which also seems to scrape at my face less while shaving.

  97. Make sure you buy from \\"panda town\\". I bought from a different seller and got a crappy metal one with bad plating that rusted that I tossed in the trash. The first one I bought from panda town was awesome. Same quality as a 30+ dollar merkur. I ordered 4 more from them in case they break I always have extras. Very mild shave, good plating, decent weight....two bucks...really...how the hell do they even ship it from Hong Kong for that price? If you get the one in a colorful package toss it in the trash. The good one comes in a white blister pack with red lettering. Dont use the pos blade that comes with it....and no I dont work for panda town...I was just impressed with the quality I got for the price.

  99. I just got an edwin jagger which is much better--i'd say that the edwin jagger is 3 to 5 times better. But the edwin jagger is 20 times more expensive. For the price, this razor is great. If you are unsure of de shaving, give this a try. It doesn't make that much of a difference for a first time shave. Honestly, in the 8 months I was using this razor, I only cut myself 2 times.<br /><br />I get very bad razor burn. Using this razor with good blades reduced that significantly. Since I got the edwin jagger, I'm more accurate with my shaving and have had even less razor burn, but this razor is still a huge step up from a crappy mach3, destroy-your-face, razor. Good razor for the price.

  104. I've been shaving with Double Edge razors for 35 years. I still use my Gillette Slim Adjustable yet today. I purchased this inexpensive razor for travel as 3 piece razors pack pretty flat.<br /><br />I was impressed by the construction. Parts are well made and solid. The solid handle has enough heft to give weight. The bottom of the head appears to be stamped heavy gauge stainless, the top piece seems to be cast zamak as many cheaper razor are. Overall, the fit and finish are better than my Lord L6 and nearly on par with vintage Gillettes. A word of warning - the head is a bit narrower than other razors. The ends of the blade stick out a bit more than on other razors.<br /><br />After a week of use, I like it. It gives a nice mild shave with a wide number of different blades, (something even my old Gillette can't do) and is very forgiving.
  105. This is a great GREAT product 1srt time got it and I used it it was great buy it it's freaking 4bucks
  106. For being so cheap in cost you really do not lose quality. It still has weight and a great finish. The grip around the shaft is also good and no really slippery. It shipped in like 5 days to my house and is still working great for me.
  107. alum. cheapie that gets the job done.
  108. If you're seriously considering buying this Double Edge Blade Razor then you're obviously not experienced in wet shaving and want to get into it, but completely unwilling to spend any serious money on another piece of metal to hold the razor that cuts hair off your face. This is your ticket!<br /><br />Wet shaving is amazing, it's benefits are endless when compared to the regular mass marketed cartridge crude, which is the Devil's work! But one of the off putting things about wet shaving is the high initial cost that comes with buying a DE razor and all the other neccesities. With this shaver that initial cost is almost completely gone.<br /><br />The build quality is impressive, the chrome plating is well done and it looks solidly made. The length is surprisingly short but is not neccesarily a negative, I'm sure the more expensive Merkuls and what not are just as small and is a benefit for control and handaling. I have extra large hands so it might just be me that the handle seems a bit short.<br /><br />Bottom Line:<br />--------------------------<br />When you want the benefits of wet shaving, or you just want to see if wet shaving is for you, buy this razor and you won't regret it.

  116. I have very sensitive skin, so much so that I usually don't shave or use the cheap single blade throw away bic razors that I pitch after one shave. Any razor with two or more blades just irritates my skin and breaks me out in razor bumps or ingrown hairs. This can be frustrating when in a professional work setting and shaving is expected, if not required.<br /><br />One day when helping my father in law move out I stumbled upon his fathers straight edge razor! I thought this would be my key to shaving success. That idea was shot down by my wife when she mentioned that I could slit my throat. Not that I would mind you but it's a possibility, also the equipment you need to maintain one can be prohibitive. So I compromised on a double edge safety razor. I'm so glad I did. This little guy get's great close sooth shaves. I went with this brand/model razor because I wasn't sure if I would like a double edge razor and did not want to drop $30 on a razor I'd want to return. At this price I figured it's cheap enough for me not to regret it.<br /><br />I'm never going back! Like many others have mentioned I actually enjoy shaving now. Before it was a chore and something I did just to get by. For anyone who wonders I would also recommend the \\"Van Der Hagen Premium Shave Set\\". You can get it through Amazon or at Walmart. Again it's my first set so I'm not getting a shaving bowl carved out of the bones of a great white whale, or a bristle made of wild Tibetan boar hairs. I'll get that later, right now I just need to show up to work with out looking like a scruffy slob. I found a 100 pack of replacement blades for about $8.00, check the reviews to see which on you want to go with. Add in some non-alcoholic after shave and your are all set. Depending on your living situation you may want to get extra blades, my wife really likes the shave I get and will sometimes use it for her self.<br /><br />***** 2012/09/25 update ******<br /><br />I've been using this razor for a while now and I'm still pretty happy with it. I doubt I'll get another razor any time soon as this one functions fine.

Is it???<br /><br />Post actual shaving is OK. I actually used a Feather blade. With some careful experience it did fine, and a bit more aggressive was an option, when compared to my Edwin Jagger. It requires a lesser steep angle for the sensitive neck areas; bit just a bit. You get used to it. If you can't go very low-pressure and get the job done within 3 total passes, then you may need a sharper blade. I'd agree a EJ tames a Feather better; but it's not a hardship using this REMEI.<br /><br />Dislike:<br />Very minor and small dark construction marks under the lid (sandwiched); but no where noticeable. Don't pay over $2 shipped though.<br /><br />I don't know why they can't show actual pictures; so I give you mine. You will need to try many DE blade brands; but not until your get your technique optimal; over at least a week. There's a lot more than huge saving to gain. This is a SAFETY razor boys, and girls. No need to fear. It's truly better. This is how you control your ZERO irritation, and the closeness level YOU choose. I'm not kidding. It's just better.

  133. I had been shaving with an electric razor for years (decades?). But I received a nice quality badger brush from my father-in-law for Christmas last year and I decided to try blades again. I loved the difference that a brush and average shaving soap made over the goop in a can, but I wasn't completely sold on all the various \\"disposable\\" razors I tried. On a whim I decided to try going fully old school and getting a DE razor set up.<br /><br />I originally purchased this razor in April for a bit more than $5. I figured at that price it wasn't much more than a single \\"Quatro\\" type razor and I could explore a little. It came with a single starter blade so I put that in and gave it a try. From the first use, I was impressed. The shave was nice and smooth and not nearly as likely to nick and pull as I found with the various Big Box Store multi blade razors. I immediately hoped on to another seller here on Amazon and bought a variety pack of 25 different blades to find the one that was right for me. While I have found ones that I like and ones that I don't like, I have continued to like the feel of this razor. It fits my hand well (admittedly, I likely have slightly below average hands) and the weight and feel is fantastic. While I had expected this to be a cheap starter razor until I got the feel of it - I had planned to maybe move up to a Merkur later - I have discovered that this one is just fine the way it is. In fact, the other day I noticed the price drop to half of what I paid only three months ago. I actually ordered two more so that I could have one just for traveling and one to put in the back of the cupboard in case this one eventually shows sign of wear. I STILL figure that at $2.59 for the razor and even factoring in the price of the blades, I'm getting a FAR nicer shave than the \\"name brand\\" disposables for a fraction of the price.

  143. 3 Stars apparently means \\"It's Ok\\" by Amazon's standards, which perfectly describes this budget safety razor.<br /><br />The weight feels like plastic, despite its claim to be \\"metal\\" (of an unspecified sort). It is also a lot smaller (shorter and slimmer) than any other safety razor I have ever used.<br /><br />That said, it's also about a fifth of the price of any of the \\"good\\" ones. For about a fifth of the price, you get more than a fifth of the performance; meaning it will cut the hairs off of your face.<br /><br />I purchased this for my travel razor, and it fills the bill on that account.<br /><br />My only complaints would be that I wish it was heavier and bigger, but for the price it is quite a deal.<br /><br />(EDIT: 9/4/14)<br />I recently purchased another one of these to keep at work, for those times I wanna go out as soon as I get off.<br /><br />I have dropped my review by one star, because this new one is junk. I don't know if they changed their method in the two years since I bought the first one or not, but this new one slices and dices my face like a handheld Cuisinart.<br /><br />The problem is clearly quality control on a cheap, and presumably cheaply made, item like this.<br /><br />Specifically, my problem seems to be that the thing is just not machined very well. The blade sits a smidge lopsided in the razor, and I don't think the sides are even, either. One side is definitely more aggressive than the other, which you can't tell at a glance.<br /><br />Overall, I still like the one I got two years ago as my travel razor, but this one just plain sucks. Buyer beware and whatnot.

  156. I grow a full beard, but I still trim the edges. Got tired of buying $30+ packs of refills for my Mach 3, especially now that I have gone back to school and am once again a broke college student. For $2 I was expecting this thing to be broken, made of plastic, or at least have casting marks and horrible tolerances. That's not the case here. This thing comes from a solid production line with good QC as far as I can tell. It feels good in my hand and has a good weight to it even though the handle is short. The head screws together exactly like it seems it should, and everything lines up, threads are good, etc.<br /><br />I decided to test it with the included blade while I wait for my Feather's to come in the mail. Holy crap, it works! And it's only $2!? Again, I only trim the edges of my beard, so I'm not doing my whole face and weird spots, but it worked pretty damn good for not even knowing how to use a double edge safety razor. I'm still working out the angle to use it. Sometimes it slices the hairs and I can't feel it at all, other times I feel the blade drag a little bit, but it cuts no matter what. I was being ultra careful not to go sideways and slice myself, and I was using super light pressure, and the damn thing worked perfectly! Screw you expensive cartridge refill packs!

  160. Given one star because there is no less than one star. From China and for this price I expected something of inferior quality - I didn't expect something this bad. The blades are wavy in the head because the head compression points are uneven and would take filing, grinding, and honing to straighten if that is even possible. Not worth anyone's time or money. You would really have to be trying to cut yourself to do some damage to your face, I love shaving with it. It's not as great as a very expensive shaver. But it's pretty darn close. Close enough if you ask me. If you need an extra travel razor or if its your first time going to a double edge, try this one. Trust me, you will love it. Reason for a 4 instead of a 5? Nothing's perfect... But I do wish it was a little bit tighter to my skin. But please don't get me wrong. It does a marvelous job and is very very durable and solid. It will not break on you and it doesn't feel cheap at all. More like an expensive razor than you might think. I wouldn't mind paying 20 times what I paid for it.

  182. I am not the one to ask when it comes to matters of shaving. I have not found a practical way to not shave so here I am. My search for a more affordable way of shaving began with the fact that plastic disposable razors provide a poor shave. Disposables are much to expensive, and generally are painful to use. After deciding a straight razor was too much of a hassle in regards to care of the razor, and the skill required to shave, I ended up looking into these double edge razors. Not wanting to spend much money on this latest experiment, I chose the seven dollar razor. If it was not for me, I cold just throw the razor in the trash. I will say, I was very surprised. After putting the blade into the handle I was off. With the first stroke down the side of my face I could hear the whiskers cleanly and painlessly being cut. I was in love. What a clean wonderful shave. Not even one nick or scratch. How had these razors escaped me for some many years/ As for the actual razor. It is of a fairly poor manufacturing. Also a little difficult to switch blades. But, with patience and care I am sure to have this razor at least for the next year. After this one breaks, I many drop 40 dollars and buy a nice brass one. But for budget minded people I highly recommend this lovely razor.
  183. My grandfather had one of these. I remember watching him shave. I was always concerned he would cut himself as I had seen him do this before with a strait razor. After my first use I am proud to say I didn't cut myself at all. I use disposables that tear my face off. I am used to the 3-4 blade disposables. this blew those out of the water. Easy to put the blade in. Just twist the handle and insert the blade that's included. Twist in the other direction to lock in the blade. I will NEVER use a disposable again. Banging the disposable on the side of the sink to knock out the clump of hairs dulls the &#34;blade&#34;. This razor you just unscrew the handle enough to create a space that the faucet can wash away the hair clumps easily. Who knew that shaving technology would move backwards? I have never used a straight razor, so I can't speak on that. This is the BEST razor I have used in years.

  190. The razor I received is branded Junjie across the top. This is the first DE safety razor I have owned and I am not disappointed. After a couple of weeks of using this I have to say I am getting the smoothest shaves I have ever had. If you have never used a safety razor before you may have to improve your technique. However this is not a big deal - it doesn't take long. I find the most important things are 1) Do not apply to much force. 2) Try to keep the blade angled at about 30 degrees. Also take short to medium length strokes rather than long strokes.<br />I will probably buy another more expensive razor but not because I want a razor that shaves better.

  193. I was looking for a cheap safety razor for my girlfriend's apartment. I bought this one mainly because of the price, and it's one of the worst decisions I've ever made.<br /><br />THE WORST POINTS:<br />All good razors incorporate the blade into a smooth line with the bevel of the razor. In contrast, this razor's blade juts out much farther than is convenient or safe, for that matter. The screw-head feels flimsy, and there's a bit of wobble even if the head is screwed down as far as you can go. I was very nervous to put it against my face.<br /><br />THE AFTERMATH:<br />After I got done with one shave, I looked like someone had backhanded me with a hedgehog. I've been wet shaving for about eight years, and I know my way around a blade. This one is hard to control, poorly designed, and not worth your time and money. I actually didn't even finish the shave; I got halfway done, saw the results, and used my girlfriend's venus to do the other side. I looked like a villain from a batman movie.<br /><br />Learn from my mistake - spend at least $20, get a good quality razor, and your face will thank you.

  197. With all the great reviewsand cheap price I figured I would try this razor as my first DE. When I received it I noticed the head of the razor wasnt perpendicular to the razor and was bent. This caused the razor to warp the blade and making the shave awful. The packaging wasnt damaged so I thought it could have been a defect, which I am perfectly fine with considering it was less than 3 dollars. Contacted the company about it and have yet to recieve a reply. I ended up purchasing a 17 dollar name brand razor and wow what a difference. I wish I never wasted the 3 dollars on this razor. Please know that you'll be taking a risk with the quality you'll recieve. Im not upset because it wasnt expensive but I'd like to inform others before they buy.

  206. It comes with a cheap blade which didn't last very long. I tossed it and replaced with a feather blade which made a huge difference. At the beginning I got some nicks and cuts but I attribute that to my limited experience rather than the razor itself.<br /><br />Here are a few things I like about it. It looks pretty good with the silver tone finish. It's has a substantial feel and weight to it. What I don't like is the screw cap at the end of the razor. It unscrews sometimes when I'm handling it while shaving. I wish the handle was a little thicker. The finish does dull quickly but can be easily polished up.<br /><br />Overall a good first razor. I would recommend it to any other novice wet shavers.

  208. I would highly recommend this razor. It gives a great shave with a good blade installed. The quality of the shave can be BBS or Baby Butt Smooth with little irritation, it all depends on you. I use a Gillette Super Platinum stainless blade the 7 O'Clock Blue Package. I know some of the reviews are negative and that may be due to Chinese quality issues. My razor is very nice. If you buy the razor inspect the blade edges after you mount the blade in the razor. The blade edges should be the same on both sides having the same amount of exposure. Recommend an Omega Synthetic Bristle Shaving Brush with Red, Blue, or Green handles available on Amazon for $8.95 Recommended also is the Omega 46001 Shaving Cream in Bowl. This is made by Proraso and a little cheaper but good. The bowl makes a shaving bowl when empty and can be filled with a variety of inexpensive soaps such as Van Der Hagen Select Shave Soap, 2.5-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 12) $23.72 If you go with the suggestions you will save a ton of money over the store products with the multiblade razors. Go to the Badger and Blade Website and look for this \\"My lathering technique with Italian soft soaps\\" With a synthetic brush shake most of the the water out and then do as the article recommends. Create the lather on your face and not in the bowl. Enjoy!

  244. Ok, so I've got super thick dark coarse hair on my legs-I grudgingly admit it. I've tried all sorts of razors and I'm never completely smooth, especially on the upper thighs-yes, I know, too much information, but it may help some of you. I did some research online and some women said a double edged razor worked great for them, so I figured I'd try. Firstly, yeah, it takes a bit longer to shave because you don't want to slice your leg open, but really, if you have any intelligence, you get the hang of it fast. This left me almost perfectly smooth for an entire day-I've NEVER had that. It did great on the upper thighs and everything else was pretty darn nice. I would 100% recommend having an aftershave lotion to help with razor burn because this really does get close. I've only used it a couple of times and my legs are still sensitive, but I'm going to assume that once the newness of the blade wears off, I'll be fine. So, for any of you ladies out there that are about ready to scream because you can't get your legs nice and smooth-try this!!! I'm so happy that I gave it a try. Let me just say that this inexpensive razor is impressive to say the least when you consider the price. It is lighter and thinner than my EJ razor and the chrome isn't as nice but you really can get a nice shave from this razor. I pulled my 5 day old Derby blade out of my EJ and popped it into this DE razor and really am appreciative of the closeness of the shave. If you're trying out DE shaving than this is your razor and then if you decide to upgrade you can use this as your travel razor.

  248. Bottomline: This thing out shaves modern expensive 5 blade razors for $2.55.<br /><br />So, this is my first classic razor. I was looking at shaving cream to help fix raw and razor burnt skin. I found this, along with a long list of advice on classic shaving and it has made all the difference. This is a great razor at an unbeatable price for transitioning from the current 5 blade disposable cartridge razors.<br /><br />I have to have a close shave every day (military). I would usually end up with at least one raw or even slightly blooded area on my face every week (usually under the chin). After a month with this razor ($2.55), a tub of Proraso shaving soap ($10), and an Ecotool Kabuki brush ($6), that is a thing of the past. The whole setup cost me less than a months worth of replaceable cartridges and the tub of shave soap will last a couple months.<br /><br />This razor seats the blade evenly and firmly. The top guard has a perfect angle to glide along your face. The chrome finish is even and smooth. The handle screws in firmly with solid threading. One day, I may upgrade to a \\"premium\\" brand, but I don't see what they could practically offer over this one.<br /><br />A couple of tips: keep your face and lather moist, go slow and easy with the razor, and let the head of the razor naturally find a good angle to go across your face. You will end up with a closer and more controllable shave than what you can get with a disposable system. If you are wondering how heavy this is, it weighs about as much as a 3 inch by 3/8 bolt.<br /><br />2 March 2014 Edit: This razor has held up great and the chrome still looks new. I did buy a Merkur Long Handled Razor. More as a commitment to classic shaving than any direct need. Comparing the two, the Merkur is machined, this one is stamped and molded. Does it make a difference? Yes, the Merkur is better. Does it make 12 times the price difference? No. So, I would still say buy this razor to start. You can always buy a premium one later and keep this one as a travel razor. That's what I am doing.emium one later and keep this one as a travel razor. That's what I am doing.

  277. Bought this as my first safety razor. Wanted a cheaper alternative to the usual 4 or 5 blade razors you always see on TV. I have fairly sensitive skin and have tried all different types of razors, shaving creams, and balms---nothing really seems to work better than another for my skin. So I figured I would give a wet shave a try since I had nothing to lose. The appeal of buying a box of blades for $10-15 that would last about a year also sounded pretty darn good (I bought a 100 count box of Astra blades for $16 shipped).<br /><br />I went with this product because of the price and the price only. I figured that if I did not care for the wet shave I would not be out that much considering some other razors out there on the market are expensive. I was surprised by how strong and sturdy the razor feel, solid metal and not plastic anywhere. It is heavy, which is good because with a wet shave you want the wight of the blade to do the cutting for you.<br /><br />It came with a single blade which seemed fairly sharp and did a nice job. The only thing I did not like about this razor was that you have to unscrew the head completely to change the blade. No fancy quick change, flip open head like the expensive ones. But then again, the savings in price is well worth it for me.
  278. If you are curious about shaving with a safety razor, this razor is perfect. The blade that it comes with is very sharp. Would also make an great travel razor.
  279. The Best Razor for the price. Wow from Japan. It's wonderful to get a shave so clean in my house. I did not have spend extra money to get a shave.
  280. I will NOT even comment on the almost 30 day turn-around!<br /><br />First of all, eight of the ten razors had the heads broken off at the head screw. None of these units were in a SKU package but only bunched together in the poorest choice of mail packaging.<br /><br />Secondly, the quality of these units were not even &#34;99 cent store&#34; quality. The metal castings were not polished or prepped for chroming showing chips and burrs under the chrome finish. The chroming was minimal at best.<br /><br />I have ordered these units before and the razors were completely different in construction, quality, SKU packaging and means of shipment.

  282. Even though this razor is well worth two dollars, your money would be better spent on a $30 Merkur, Parker, etc. The bottom piece on these generic razors don't protrude offering non of the safety of a safety razor. On this item the blade protrudes. In addition the blade is not shaped by the top piece. I shave my face and head daily. With this razor I often had razor burn and had to go over areas multiple times. Blades only lasted me one shave of both face and head. I used feather lites and had trouble getting close. I shaved after shower w secret shave or proraso as pre shave. Then I apply proraso shave soap. Still I had irritation and nicks. I decided to get a Merkur. I shaved my face first pass against the grain, pain free, nice and close in a quarter of the time it took me with this generic razor. Derby blades weren't sharp enough w this razor but they get close enough with the Merkur I purchased.
  283. The quality on this DE razor is fantastic for the price paid (and quite good for a bit more money too). I paid 3-4 times as much for a much, MUCH more cheaply-made razor. I expected this one to be my backup razor but it is my primary. Perfect option for a &#34;starter&#34; DE razor. Feels sturdy, the mold is clean (no burrs in the metal), it locks the blade in nicely and it feels comfortable in my hand. Definitely recommend for a beginner to DE razors or for a spare for travel or whatnot.

I also don't hear her cussing in the shower like she did when shaving her legs with the track 2 type razors.<br />UNLIKE the track two, or three or four razors you can EASILY rinse all the gunk off the blade in a safety razor. The blades are CHEAP and last for MANY shaves saving us a LOT of money.<br />I bought a more expensive one with the twisty handle to make changing blades easier and now keep this one in the shower. (The wife got TICKED when I kept using hers).<br />Bought a mug with shaving soap and a brush but I also like &#34;Shave Magic&#34; which is probably just mineral oil.<br />I highly recommend the &#34;Feather&#34; blades from Japan or &#34;Personna&#34; blades from the 99 Cents Store but there are several different brands.<br />Drug stores carry the double edged blades for safety razors but NOT the razors. Can't find the safety razors at Walmart. Can't find them at Target. Seems you can ONLY find them on Amazon, eBay or other internet sites. Why is this? It's because the razor companies make a FORTUNE selling disposable blades that only give men a couple of good shaves or electric razors with replacement blades at OBSCENE prices.<br />A safety razor is MUCH less irritating on your skin and saves you a TON of money.<br />You only have to read the reviews on ANY of the brands of safety razors to see that the overwhelming number of men who try them LOVE them.   291. I use this razor to shave my legs and arms, yes I am female. This razor will cut you if you shave too fast, so it makes me slow down. It gives a very close shave. I love the fact that I can buy the replacement blades anywhere. A blade will last me about a month. And when not in use I can take it apart and put the top back on upside down and it won't cut. The top does have a tendency to unscrew if you don't watch it, but all you have to do it tighten it. My husband even borrows it every once and a while, all he has to do is change the blade. He likes it too, but he like to shave like it's a race. I like to shave at my own time. I would recommend this razor and for the price I'm thinking of getting a second. What else do you need?<br /><br />As a side note, I'm a total convert to safety razor shaving now, after moving up over the past 10 years from double edge disposables all the way to 6 blade vibrating handle contraptions that cost me $100 a year in blades. I bought 100 pack of the Derby blades, which is literally a 4 year supply for me for 8 bucks (I change blades every other week or less). $8 is what I would spend in one month on the Gillette's of the world. It takes a few shaves to get down, but once you do, you'll feel like a real man that knows money is better spent on beer, not blades.

  307. 11 December 2013<br /><br /> If you are anything like me, you like Gillet’s Mach3 razor but hate the skyrocketing price of replacement blades and are looking for a more economical way to shave. As a kid, I remember going to the barber shop with my father, watching him get a cut and a shave with a straight razor. Remembering the pleasant smells of the old barber shop got me thinking. Could I save money by shaving with a straight razor? I’m sure I could, but do I trust myself with a blade to my neck first thing in the morning? I decided that a double edge safety razor might be a better idea for me.<br /> Being an Amazon Prime member, I began actively searching Amazon’s website in hopes of finding a less expensive way to shave. Being new to the world of double edge shaving, I was not willing to splurge on the high end razors that range from thirty to sixty bucks because I’m trying to be thrifty. After navigating through the vast archives of customer reviews and recom-mendations of double edge razors, I came across this Silver Tone Double Edge Blade Razor with Nonslip Metal Handle for $3.98. Since the time of this posting the razor’s price has dropped to $2.00. The item was not Prime but the seller (amjimshop) stated that shipping was free. A seller rating of 4.7 stars out of 5 and a product rating of 4 out of 5 stars helped ease most of my appre-hensions about buying this razor. Here is the link to the item: [[ASIN:B0050HO9MI Silver Double Shaver Nonslip Handle]]<br /> Something that you may want to consider before purchasing this razor is, this item does ship from China and will take several weeks to reach those of us that live in the United States. I neglected to realize how long shipping would take and started to panic at about the two week point (I think mine came on the slow boat from China). I, in turn, ordered my second choice ra-zor, a Lord Premium Safety Razor model L6 for $13.49. The Lord razor was a Prime item, so I received it in two days with free shipping. Coincidentally, I received the Lord Razor the day after I received my Silver Tone Razor. One thing that concerned me about buying an item from China was that China is widely known for their use of lead in products (lead is known to cause cancer). I read that another reviewer had the same concern and tested their razor for lead. To his and my relief the test was negative.<br /> For my first shave with a safety razor I used my Silver Tone Razor with the less than ad-equate blade included. Getting the blade to align strait in the head of the razor took a little effort, a bit of a design flaw in my opinion and surly nothing that can’t be worked around. The razor is made of some kind of metal that has a bit of heft to it and a pleasant chrome finish on it. The handle seems to be on the short side at around 3.5 inches whereas, the Lord Razor is approxi-mately 4 inches. I have currently been using my Silver Tone Razor for approximately four months now on a regular basis, and it shows no sign of wear. The handle has grooves in it to aid with traction while shaving.<br /> I have come to the conclusion that it is possible for me to save money by switching from Mach3 disposable razors to double edge safety razors. The initial investment consists of a razor, glycerin soap, mixing bowl, a badger bristle brush, and double edge blades. I have found that the savings are in the double edge blades. For example, I found a 15 count package of Mach3 blades on Amazon Prime for $33.74. I purchased 100 Astra double edge blades on Amazon Prime for $12.69. I have found that on average, I can get a week more from a double edge Astra blade than I can from a Mach3 blade. The longer I shave with a double edge razor the greater my savings will be. I have also come to realize that the shave snobs who give this razor, now $2.00 on Ama-zon, a poor rating are comparing it to their more than $30.00 razor.<br /> I was not expecting this Silver Tone Razor to have all the luxuries or features that a top of the line razor has. I bought it to help me cut my shaving costs. This razor does the job and does it well for the price. I even like it better than the Lord L6 I bought. The bottom line is this razor shaves my face better that a Mach3 razor, and the longer I use it the more money I will save.
  308. It was an old razor and I haven't really had much experience with this kind of razor. Though the thought was nice. Seems cool but beards today are a lot harder to deal with.
  309. This product does not feel as sturdy in your hand as others I've held and I'm a little worried it's going to come unscrewed and slice my face open when I shave with it.   333. I bought this figuring, &#34;lets see what double edge (DE) shaving is like. If this works out, ill upgrade&#34;.   334. Holds a razor blade and cuts whiskers, it's fine. Not as good as razors in the good old days of course.
  335. about what i expected, terrible blade, cheap and that says it all, but thought i would try it for something different
  336. While the razor appraires worth multiple times more then I paid for it it has a major design flaw. The razor can not securely hold a blade in a constant position. The blade wiggles around when not fully screwed down. The blade shouldn't move at all. Ultimately what you end up with is a blade that's protruding farther on one side then the other. Or worse not level and at an angle. This will give you a couple problems. Cuts/nicks Removing to much skin on one side and not enough hair on the other. What is worse is since you can't get it to hold a blade in a consistent position you never really get the feel of the correct angle. Since one side will give you an aggressive cut and the other side will be very mild. None the less its a cheap razor, and I'm not trying to bash it. But to get the hang of DE razors you need consistence between shaves and the razor just provides far to much variables. If you line the blade up evenly on both ends and level it gives a good shave. While this shaver is cheap/cast metal it wouldn't take much to widen the support racks that hold the blade. 98% of all blades are designed to a universal. A little thicker support will not make it any worse by elimating possible support for a certain type of blade. Ultimately for its price its not bad. As long as you pay attention to the feedback that the razor gives and make sure its correctly centered it will make a good stepping stone to gauge if DE razors are for you. --UPDATE-- Last year I decided to replace this razor with an Edwin Jagger and it make a world of difference. I've single shave I've had so far with the Edwin Jagger has been flawless. I regret not upgrading sooner. I got the idea that it's the blades that cut your beard and the razor is simply a device to hold that blade. I was wrong, the razor defiantly effects how the blade works and in this case it was a dramatic difference. If your just testing out DE shaving and your on a tight budget like I was this will work. However please keep in mind you will get significantly better shaves with a more expensive razor. I stuck with this razor for nearly 2 years. I had many good shaves and many bad shaves, just figured it was normal after so long. I was wrong. After upgrading to a well known brand of razors it made a huge difference and I haven't had a bad shave since I've retired this thing.
  337. It was not what I expected not but it worked I was looking for the type that opened with split top
  338. Not a bad looking razor, especially for the ridiculously low price. I bought two. It takes a while for them to ship from China. Chrome finish is pretty good. Not sure about the quality of the underlying material - - my guess is that it's overseas &#34;mystery metal.&#34; This is a three-piece razor. Time will tell how well the screw threads hold up to repeated blade changes. Again, though, the price is unbeatable.<br /><br />As for the shave, the cutting angle is bit more aggressive than that of my Merkur - - but I like it. Be careful if you're used to a milder shave. The handle is short, making this razor a good choice for the travel kit. If you like dual-edge shaving, you should try this out for the price alone. Durability could be a concern . . . .
  339. It doesn't seem to tighten down enough to get the correct spacing/angle for the blade. I used the blade it came with and also the Feather blades and the shaves were both awful. It was only $2 with free shipping so I wasn't expecting much. I'll buy a better safety razor and toss this one.
  340. Let's be clear here.This is a safety razor.It is not frilly.It has no bells and whistles.If You want a trendy Steam-Punkish Safety Razor that You can prop up in a little display by your bathroom sink in hopes of impressing someone with your swank suavity you are probably young and should spend several dozen dollars on a cool retro-razor:If you want a very frugally priced razor that does what razors do?....You can't go wrong with this one......I give it four stars not because it's incredible and amazing but because I didn't receive the first one and after I contacted the seller and made this known to them they sent another promptly in spite of the fact that it was probably a loss for them.That is good business....and it does what it's supposed to do...It's not a fashion statement:It's a TOOL You shave your face with! :) and it does that effectively sometimes no frills is the way to go.
  341. The blade that comes with this razor should be disposed of immediately. The handle is too short so I have to take more care using. I will use it as a travel razor but not my main one.
  342. I have had this razor for a few months now and have used it everyday since it arrival. I'm useing Derby blades which get changed out weekly. I feel that this offers a better shave than the fusion I used for many years. there are review of the head breaking but if that happens for the low price of the razor and blades I will order another.<br /><br />I would suggest this product to anyone in the marked to lessen the blow of the expesive blades.

I have never used a safety razor before and it certainly takes a bit of getting used to, but now that I have I don't think I would ever go back to spending $27 every two weeks for throw away razors. I paired this with the feather razors also here on Amazon have shaved 6 times and still have noticed no significant dulling of the razors. Nice badger brush, Colonel Conk soap, wow! talk about luxury! Very happy with this purchase! Would recommend!

  347. You get what you pay for. This may be good for a few days if something happens to may real razor.

  354. I just unpacked this and tossed a fresh astra blade in it. I was excited to try a new DE on the cheap, espescially given so many positive reviews. Unfortunately in my case you get what you pay for. I didn't expect a work of art with this, but an even level of agression is pretty important with a DE. One side looks nice and even, but when mine was pressed at the factory, something didn't go quite right and one side has a decided slope in the gap. I will have to be mindful to use only one side on a DE razor and thus, this thing is going in the trash after I try out the good side and decide if I want to roll the dice and buy another. What do you expect for under 3 dollars?
  355. Keeping the cheap price in mind, this is still a bad deal.<br /><br />I got this due to the mostly good reviews but I wish I'd skipped it.<br /><br />A good portion of the head and the closing mechanism is made of plastic. I used this once and it will now not lock the blade in place. If you turn the ring to lock the blade into the proper shape it just keeps turning and slips open again. You can only tighten it so far before it slips. When I shaved with it, it was probably coming apart slightly. It shaved decently in places but I did nick the heck out of my chin. I'm new to safety razor shaving so some of this can be chalked up to inexperience but I don't think this razor reliably holds the blade correctly.<br /><br />I mainly wanted to get this to see if shaving this way agreed with me and so I think it did it's job. I'll get a quality razor next time.
  356. I didn't think there was much craftsmanship or precision needed to make one of these, but I was wrong. I bought this to have a travel razor. I use a Merkur at home. The Merkur is better for a couple of reasons: 1) precision build - blades sit securely and consistently. This cheap version can be aligned straight but it takes a little effort that I'd rather not rely on my naked eye for. 2) It feels cheap and light. Bottom line is that it is serviceable for a couple bucks, especially if it is not used very often. The Merkur costs $40 and probably isn't 20x better, but for something I use every day, I prefer consistency and security.

  377. Well, the first round of razors was a bummer. My 3 never came from the seller &#34;Beautiful life&#34; but I did get a prompt refund. The handle does not thread smoothly onto the head and the head vs handle is at a slight angle. I bent the guards back a bit with some cloth (the bottom plate's edges are much sharper than the rimei below) and I think the razor will still shave.<br /><br />The concern is that just getting a &#34;sodial&#34; or &#34;silver tone&#34; razor on amazon may result in you getting a junjie. No thanks.<br /><br />I reordered more from THIS link (via the currently absent seller &#34;Panda Town&#34;) instead: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00A7239EK/ref=oh_details_o01_s00_i00?ie=UTF8&psc=1<br /><br />As far as I can see, all the hong kong sellers sell the good RIMEI ones.<br /><br />The 3 new &#34;RiMei&#34; razors I received are much, much better quality. They came in a red/white packaging with the RiMei brand and they rock. The major difference between the two besides for the quality is that the RiMei ones have two nubs/bumps attached to the top plate that stick out of the bottom plate. I put a little bit of lithium grease on the handle's threads and now it's pretty damn smooth. Everything about this razor feels higher quality than the crap junjie above even though they look pretty similar.<br /><br />If I can track down more $2 RiMei razors, i'll be buying more as gifts. By the time someone wears one of these out s/he will know whether DE shaving is something they will generally want to pursue or not.

I've been using this for about two weeks now.<br /><br />First impression this razor feels heavy, surprisingly well made for what I paid. If bought in a store in the U.S. This feels like a 30 dollar razor. Nice ergonomics for my thick hands.<br /><br />As for how it works? I let my beard grow for a few days, I looked like grizzly Adams by then. So I tried the razor hoping it wouldn't be too painful. Some cold water, thick beard Barbasol, and ten minutes later, my chubby face is as smooth as a baby's bottom. No nicks, very little deep pulling.<br /><br />Couple of days later my five o clock shadow is back, I'm quite hairy, but not much so the double edge went pretty deep. Replacement blades is the only draw back, about 16 bucks a pack. Tip of the day. Keep the blade dry after use by removing it after use and dry them thoroughly each time and each blade should last more than a few months.

  397. So I figured, &#34;A two dollar razor! I've gotta try it at that price! How bad could it be?&#34; HA! Well first, the razor I received isn't what was pictured. I know some folks order this razor and are thrilled to receive a decent shaver, a ReMei. I did not get this. I got a Shenglong twist-to-open. The handle is metal, but the twist knob and butterfly doors are silvery plastic...which should have been a warning. I know the workers in factories in China are known for their precision when putting together my smartphone, but this precision was not present in this razor. When I closed the doors on a blade, I could tell that I was going to have a bad time. The blade gap looked more like something my wife uses to slice potatoes. Stupidly, I decided to give it a try. I made it about an inch down one cheek. It was the kind of pain that makes people give up a terrorist's secret hideout. Now maybe a better blade would have made a difference, but I doubt it. I may remove the blade and let my three-year-old &#34;shave with daddy&#34; but I worry that just the sight of the razor in my bathroom will give me flashbacks. This is an awful razor. Save up for a Edwin Jagger, or pick up any old Gillette at a flea market if you're looking for a bargain. This razor is not what you want.

  403. I always enjoy using this razor. It's an old double-edged one, using double edge blades which are much simpler and cheaper to buy than the ones sold by, say, Gillette (i.e. multi-blade refills). You should know that unlike most modern double edge systems, it does not have the twist handle that opens up the blade area for replacement. You have to unscrew the shaving head and then lift off the cover and put a new blade into a slot. Though it sounds difficult, it really only takes an additional minute and you do not change blades every day anyway.<br />The finish on the razor is good out of the box and after a year, it's still perfect. This is one of those things in life that you buy and it accompanies you everywhere, forever. On those terms, it's mighty affordable at that...

  439. Don't be fooled by the price or the Hong Kong foolishness here. I have three of these razors for leaving at various places where they might get &#34;misplaced&#34;!!!! I ordered the first one as a gag gift but when it arrived I was surprised at the construction and decided to tamper with and use it a couple of times.<br />I took a small piece of emery paper and carefully polished the edges of the cap just to insure a completely even contact with the blades and then I filled the hole in the handle with Vaseline to lubricate the threads and prevent rust if that were to be an issue. I ONLY TIGHTEN THE HANDLE FINGER TIGHT enough to snug the blade in place. There is no need to warp the blade or damage the threads by doing any more tightening than I just mentioned.<br />This little razor has a fine, solid type safety bar that absolutely works!!!! I've been shaving with DE razors for 60 years and I know something about the things. This is as gentle a cut as you will achieve with a DE!!<br />I have a Weber stainless that is a fine, precision, polished DE shaving piece ... I even lubricate the threads on the handle of that fine instrument!!!!
  440. I like this handle a lot and it's nearly perfect, just wish it was a little heavier. It does the job well though.

SO not sure how this product really is, because we never got it :(
  442. This Chinese razor is priced appropriately for the price. It provides a good shave, but the handle is too short for my hand. It is also quite slippery when wet and difficult to turn with one hand. Loading the blades is a bit clumsy. You have to take it apart down to its bra and panties just to change blades. I ended up buying the Parker 96R, and I am glad I did.
  443. I bought it because of the price like everyone else, but even at 2.50, I feel taken advantage of.   444. Arrived in just under a month. The guard is cheap, thin, weak, and worst of all, crooked. I cut my face on the first down stroke. Save your money and put it on a Lord L6 [[ASIN:B004N77JVY Premium Safety Razor Model LP1822L]] currently for $12.75
  445. This uses the standard double edge variety (super thin) razor blades. Nobody sells the double blade inserts anymore in this country, but you can always buy them here online. I purchased the feather brand from Nippon that took 2.5 weeks to arrive from Tokyo. Simple to open and change blades. It screws apart with three pieces (handle, top guard, and notched base where blade sits). I use it mainly to keep my hairline clean, to get my neck where my electric shaver does a poor job, and because if you have one of these rather weighty razors, it is hard to break or lose it. I put it on display in my bathroom, and it is attractive next to my badger-hair shaving brush. I built my own razor stand for it. The very best part about it is---no more wasting money on cheap plastic disposable razors, which are also overpriced. It does not provide the same comfort of shave as a triple or quadruple blade, but it is good for the budget, which makes me happy. It is also kind of nostalgic, like record players or other old-timey stuff.
  446. This is a mild razor not aggressive at all. Throw away the razor blade that comes with the safety razor. It was dull and scraped my skin. I put in a Dorco razor blade and it shaved OK. I needed several passes to get my beard off. This is a cheap razor that takes about 3 to 4 weeks to arrive. If you need a cheap travel razor this is the one to get. I never take my more expensive safety razors when traveling. I have several under $10 razors that I use when on trips.

  452. I bought this to give DE shaving a try before dropping $30 on a razor that I might only use a few times. I really didn't expect much for less than $3, but I at LEAST thought it would be functional!! If you look closely at the pictures of real razors, you can see that the components are machined. In the case of the &#34;silver tone&#34; it is stamped out of low grade &#34;pot metal&#34;, which I expected. However, the stampings were so crudely made that the head had a U shaped indent on both sides that caused the blade to bow when installed. One look at that and I told myself there was NO WAY I was putting it anywhere near my face! Disappointed and determined to at least get to USE my $2 paperweight, I broke out my file and went to work. After no less than 50 passes on each side (seriously) with a 12&#34; bastard file, the blade finally sat straight. I gave it a try and actually got a pretty decent shave. I guess it served it's intended purpose, as I'm ready to try a real DE razor. Not to be completely negative, It shipped from Hong Kong much sooner than expected. Products like this shouldn't even be on the market, but in all honesty, if it weren't for cheap, foolish Americans like myself, there would BE no market for trash like this.

  487. OK, so this is the 2nd \\"ultra-cheap\\" double edge razor I have ordered from China through Amazon. (Both were less than $3.00 with FREE shipping). This razor, (a \\"RIMEI\\" brand), came sealed on a red and white store display card, and is extremely-good quality for the price! Keep in mind, this is NOT a $50.00 Merkur Razor; this is a ridiculously-inexpensive \\"back-up\\" razor that actually WORKS! It does take some care and attention to change the blade, as this razor is not as robust as other 3-piece Safety Razors, but the head does hold the blade securely, and the razor shaves well. I suppose the only thing I am really having trouble with is trying to figure out how something like this can be manufactured, assembled and packaged in China, shipped across the Pacific ocean and delivered to the middle of the Arizona desert for less than $3.00? This is one crazy experiment with an unusually-happy ending.
  488. For the price, this is an incredible value. It's reasonably well made, though I don't think my heirs will argue over it (if it still works more than 2-3 years from now).   497. This does exactly what it says. It is a competent razor handle of sound construction. The blades are available just about anywhere in the world, and there are many brands to choose from. If you enjoy Cold War era nostalgia, or just want to try your hand at shaving the same way your father did when he was your age; this is worth the price. Shave lightly, and expect a few small cuts your first few times. These are not the idiot proof razors of today, your technique, and choice of blades will make all the difference in the world. I would recommend picking up a sampler pack of razor blades to experiment and find out what you like best. (also available on Amazon by searching for &#34;Razor Blade Sampler Pack&#34;) You may find that a blade from a company you have never heard of, like Big Ben, Astra, Treet or Lord fits your face better than your Bic or Gillette. Bonus Tips: Shave daily, rinse the blade after every stroke, use soap or creme instead of just water. Don't even think about dry shaving.

  520. Who else is sick and tired of spending a small fortune on shaving cartridges? My breaking point was when I went to buy the newest 5-blade hyped refill pack and found an 8 pack to be nearly $40. $40!! Couldn't believe it. I have really sensitive skin and I razor burn if I even think about shaving so I'm always trying the newest blade system out there.<br /><br />I wanted to try out a safety razor but didn't want to spend too much in start-up in case I didn't like it. I figured I'd give it a try for $10 (razor plus a pack of Astro blades). I gotta say, I wont go back to a cartridge again. It takes some getting used to, and after a few small cuts you get it. The shave is as close as any cartridge system and I bought 50 more 5-pack of blades that will likely last me through the year (and then some) for less than $30.<br /><br />This particular razor is fine for starting out. I do plan to upgrade my razor soon and keep this as a travel razor. Upside: buying a new razor does not mean my blades are worthless. The blades fit any handle, so no more buying different cartridges for different razor handles. I use shaving gel, but it's recommended by the &#34;experts&#34; to use shaving soap and a brush to lather. I'll stick with the gel for now.

One style came in a red and white card pack, while the other style was in a blue and gray card pack. The red/white packaged razor had a better finish, better blade alignment, shaved a bit smoother, and seemed to be of slightly higher quality than the razor in the blue/gray packaging. Both are labeled Reimi, but are different models. Each works, but the red/white packaged one is a little better overall.

The Gillette has a longer handle and is adjustable AND is the butterfly type rather than this razor which is the take-it-apart version. Both work, but I like the adjustability of the older Gillette.<br /><br />The reason that old razor still works is that I keep my razors clean. A dirty razor is an invitation to a bad shave. (FYI)

The only thing I wish was that it was easier to change the blades, but this is likely the case with all double edge razors or there is an easy way of doing it and I haven't found out yet.
  539. Very well built and heavy. It takes very little pressure to get a great shave. And the handle has a really nice feel. Very good quality and well worth the cost.
  540. This has a nice solid feel to it. Simple and sturdy. built to last. The blade that came with it is razor-sharp that provided a very close shave.
  541. I got this for my father. He really liked it. It cut close and worked well. The only problem he had with it is that is was very easy to cute himself with it. Just be careful.
  542. I bought as an extra stocking stuffer for my bf. It was in a case and looks really neat but hurts when shaving and doesn't do a good job at all.
  543. I bought this thing for $2. It took about 3 weeks to arrive. I'd recommend tossing the blade it comes with and putting your own in (Feather, Gillette, whatever double edged blade suits you) before you try shaving with it, and the handle feels and looks more like it's made from plastic than stainless steel, although it's well balanced and feels nice. However, none of that matters. It cost $2 at the time of my purchase, and it provides a better shave than any Gillette or Schick razor out there. It tightens well and holds the blades perfectly, it's solid, and it gives me a wonderful, baby smooth shave every time, just be careful if/when going against the grain (you probably shouldn't do that anyway). This might have topped my list for the best thing I've ever bought for less than $5. Come on. Try it. You won't regret it.
  544. This is my first DE razor and I've read many reviews and websites about them. A few months ago I switched to a brush and shave soap and ditched the can for good. A few weeks ago I received my razor in the mail. I didn't expect much, I knew I spent very little, and usually I get what I pay for. I just didn't want to invest too much to see if DE shaving was for me.<br />This razor actually surprized me. It has a nice weight, easy to handle, and it seems to be of a decent quality. I ordered blades separately as well, and used the included razor for about a week until the others came. I have no idea what brand the blade was since I don't read the language on it. It was just a little grabby, but i compensated with more lather. Maybe I needed more anyway.<br />I'm satisfied. Later in the year I'll spend more for a different brush and razor. For now I'm good and learning the ropes.

It has a nice weight, good machining, and I believe it will last a very long time. If you are tired of being ripped off by gimmicks, get this razor.

You then have to put the bottom piece back on, carefully set the blade on the bottom piece, and then put the top piece and, while carefully screwing it all back together.<br />The best place to hold the top piece while you are screwing it all back together seems to be right on the blade itself.
  555. I suffer from significant razor bump and ingrown hairs and I have tried a countless variety of modern shaving products to combat the issue. I was given some advice from a colleague about using a safety razor and figured I would give it a shot. I shopped around and noticed they were all around the $30+ price range, which was a little steep for something that might not work for me at all. Then I came across this razor and I immediately ordered it after realizing how cheap it was. Shipping took a little while but it came from Hong Kong so that was to be expected. The razor was as I expected in terms of quality and weight but the handle was slightly small but not unmanageable for my medium sized hands. I put it to work immediately with the blade that came with it(bonus in itself) and it worked wonders. I have since been using it to shave almost every day and I have noticed some significantly less ingrown hairs and slightly less irritation and razor bump. It is fairly easy to use and takes only a few shaves to get the hang without nicking yourself. All in all, this is a great product for the price and if you are not familiar with safety razors and want to give it a try, this is just the product for you.
  556. Many years back I went to the new double blade style of razor and it did help prevent nicking and over the years I went up to five blades per razor! Suddenly it occurred to me the cost skyrocketed and the shave isn't all that impressive. I know now that this double edge blade razor gives just as close or closer shave, much cheaper for blade replacements which hold up almost as long before replacement is necessary, and is easier to get around those areas on my face that require finer manipulating.<br /><br />I would like a longer handle and may sometime buy one but I highly recommend this razor.

  568. DO NOT USE THE BLADE THE COMES WITH THIS RAZOR! I recently bought this razor to get into wet shaving and absolutely love it.
