My only complaint is that the razor it comes with is useless. I've used dollar store disposables for a month that cut better than it did. I ordered a pack of Astra's at the same time and only tried the blade it came with out of curiosity, big mistake. They would be better off just not including the blade. You can get like 100 Astra's for ~$11 on Amazon so I'd suggest that or buy a sampler pack as everyone's face is different and will react to different blades. My girlfriend just ordered one of these after seeing how much better of a shave I got with mine. If this is your first time wet shaving, go on youtube and watch videos on how to get a good shave. If you're anything like me, you've been shaving wrong most of your life and with a few small changes, you'll be getting the best shave of your life.

  595. this thing sucks do not buy it it will cut you up
  596. Luckily I bought and got used to shaving using an old Gilette Tech, so I had a decent idea what I was doing. On my first pass with this razor and the included blade I cut and nicked myself something fierce, so as an experiment I put the blade in the Tech for the second pass. The Tech had no problems with the blade, so I loaded up the razor with a Derby Extra, the same brand of blade I learned on the Tech with. On my third pass (across the grain the other way) I had better luck and noticed my soap lather was better so I went against my better judgement and decided to use it on my fourth/final pass. The foam was absolutely perfect for the final pass, something I can say I haven't achieved too often, but has become more frequent, in the past couple weeks. After having used it on a couple of passes and remembering things that I wasn't used to worrying about with the Tech, the fourth/final pass was my best pass with the razor.<br /><br />If you have patience and are willing to make sure everything is absolutely perfect with your technique and lather on every single pass, then this could be the razor. But if you haven't ever used a safety razor before, I highly recommend a different razor just simply due to the extraordinarily steep learning curve...if this had been my first DE, I probably would have begun reconsidering the entire idea, but with even my minimal experience with the Tech I was able to sort through the difficulties and improve my results just within the same shave.<br /><br />That said, the Tech I have been using has a lighter handle so I wasn't as conscious of letting the weight do the work which is a BIG must with this one (one of the things it reminded me). On my first pass I could tell the lather was thin, but figuring it would be as forgiving as the Tech I wasn't too concerned...this razor isn't forgiving, if anything is wrong with your shave you will see the evidence on your face in the mirror. However, not my best shave to date and my face still burnsfrom the shave...I'll give it a few more chances before I decide if I'm going to set it back for a bit, just because it does show potential to work really well (thinking it'll become my travel razor if I ever adjust to it, otherwise I might use disposables for that purpose).<br /><br />UPDATE: My experience with it has gotten better as I have used it more.

  646. Ordered this razor and the Sodial both on May 6th of 2014. One arrived a few days ago. One arrived the next day after that. I cannot read Chinese characters so not sure which is which? Cannot see the name of the razor or the seller that matches my order on either package. The first to arrive was a plastic, clamshell design. Even though both that I ordered were the 3 piece design where the handle unscrews and you take the rest apart to insert a blade. The clamshell one says it is an SK brand on the package. If you liked Yugos you will love that one. It is a cheap piece of plastic garbage. But, it was worth the low price for a few laughs. Looks like it might work IF you can get the top to close after you insert the blade. Takes some jiggling around to make that happen. Then you have to loosen the handle a bit and mess with the blade to get it straight. Looked pretty scary and I was not about to try that one on my face. Saved a bit of my forearm and it took some hair off. Have not used it since. The second one that came actually looks like the picture on Amazon. It is a Ri,Mei brand. Hopefully that does not mean \\"cut me\\" in Chinese. It actually looks pretty good and fewer parts to break or jam up. Still have to manually straighten the blade before tightening the handle to get it straight. Have not tried that one on my face yet either. Waiting for my order of Feather blades before I risk shaving with it. But it looks like it \\"might\\" work OK for a cheap starter single blade shaver. Keeping my fingers crossed. My old 3 blade razors are looking better all the time. BTW pretty wild that these can be shipped all the way from China for under $3. This company must want US dollars very badly.

  658. I purchased this razor when I happened across it because I was interested in getting a double edge razor and this seemed like a very inexpensive way to &#34;try it out&#34;. My first experience was not very good. Bad razor burn and nicks abounded. I would have probably given it up had I not also ordered the twin pack of Feather blades that Amazon recommended with this product. The problem is not the razor, it is the blade! I highly recommend if you try this product, you trash the Chinese blade that is included and try it with a better razor blade. Once I switched to the feather blades, I have been very satisfied with my razor. Now, this is not an $80 DE razor. You won't be ditching a Merkur to switch to this razor. But its is fairly well constructed and a good starter for someone interested in DE shaving.<br />The actual brand is Ri,Mei (Yes, with the comma), a Chinese conglomerate that makes a plethora of products. The razor is reasonably heavy, and the butt of the handle can be removed to add BB's or shot to increase the weight. All of the threads line up nicely and the razor is easy to use when its time to change blades. It holds the blades securely and straight. Once you ditch the cheapo blade included it shaves nicely. I have noticed some corrosion<br />I have since found several reviews by experienced shavers online who recommend this model as an inexpensive travel razor that won't break the bank if lost. It is a very mild razor, so its very good for people with sensitive skin, but for guys like me, who have heavy beards, it may be better to seek a more aggressive razor. Overall, a nice product for the money. Oh, and it takes a LONG time to arrive.
  659. Cannot complain about anything. These blades also seem to hold an edge, and shave me close. Each seems to last me over a month, but of course, I don't write down when I change blades. I might have a lifetime supply of blades.
  660. Not complicated, but does give me a VERY close shave! The handle unscrews to change blades, not a fold open razor. Most parts do not rust, but I do take it apart to clean after each shave. DO NOT press down or shave quickly, it isn't like using a straight razor, BUT you will bleed if you do. I use the Personal double edge blades, and it feels almost like I'm shaving with a straight razor.<br /><br />My tough old beard gets a close shave, which electrics and many blade disposables can't do. Fancy it isn't but it will last longer than any electric, and I can't find any others to beat it. Maybe the old ones from years back, but I couldn't find any of those.

  672. i ordered & receiver this razor which came in a bubble bag all three parts loose with no wrapping at all, and 1 wrapped blade. I first put it together to ensure its straightness which appears fine. The blade fits well, though the blade guide pins should be wider to prevent blade movement and better stability. The craftsmanship is better then expected for the price. (Approx handle sizes) This is 1.9 oz 3-1/2&#34; handle. Nothing near the Merkur 34c 2.7 oz 3.0&#34; handle or Edwin Jagger lbl89 2.6 oz 2-15/16&#34; handle, but then again, we are looking at price. The unit lacks the desired weight and feels unbalanced. I loaded a Gillette blue blade, and after ensuring the blade was seated properly, I began my shave. I find this item appears to be more on the aggressive side causing skin burn. It appears that one side may have a bigger blade gap, but hard to determine without an instrument. The guard comb has extremely narrow grooves that causes the shave soap to be completely removed before the blade cuts the hair. I don't get this with my other razors. The long thin handle feels cheap but not slippery. I prefer the short thicker handle for better weight balance and of course better control. The good: Low price, ok for the money but would not recommend it for your daily tool. Being an economical item, I will use it as a travel piece, so if it gets lost, stolen, or taken away at an airport, no biggie. Finish is fine for the $$. The bad: Too light, not balanced. Long thin handle feel like a disposal. Less control over a thick short handle, that may cause u to press like a plastic disposable, causing greater skin burn. Razor burn from narrow comb groves. Summary: In other reviews, some got bad units, bent, crocked. I was lucky to get a decent one. So if u decide to purchase one, check it throughly before putting it to your skin. Thanks Update comments added : I see a lot of reviews from first time DE users. For those, not knowing the difference, really get yourself a better razor in the 20-30 range, get experience then if u want get this for a spare or to compare. With the razor and blade gap I was not going to use a feather sharp blade to begin with. I elected a more forgiving razor. Also going from disposals, to DE, the user has a tendency of pressing the razor against the skin causing more niches, and ingrown hair cuts.

Are there better razors out there, yes... but for someone that is switching from the Mach 15 (of whatever is available now) to a traditional razor, it is an amazing buy. Here are the facts: It is made of metal, It is a three piece design, it is made in China. Bottom line, for a novice double edge razor shaver, go for it... it is a decent razor for such little coin!

  710. This razor is made as poorly as possible, but it is usable. However, I am not sure how long it will last. There really isn’t much I can say about this razor. I don’t think it is stainless steel. I think it is made out of tin. Amazingly enough, the blade compartment where it touches the face is very straight with smooth edges. It is a 3 piece razor, and it holds the blade evenly and securely, but you have to be very careful when putting the blade in and removing it. The one I received, the handle does not screw to the blade guard smoothly, and I have to use force to tighten it and this could be dangerous. I think mine has stripped screw threads. The blade is a bit more exposed in this razor than most other razors, so you could cut yourself if you are not carful. The bottom line is that I don’t recommend this razor even if it is very cheap.   715. One blade is all a man needs. All these new commercial products with 5 or 6 blades is insane. It doesn't make sense for me. People complain about the pain with one blade, but they don't realize that they aren't really using a blade as much as their using a thin piece of metal. With this product, you're getting a blade that is incredibly thin yet durable.<br /><br />The double edged feature makes it even better since you can replace the blade (or sharpen, if you prefer) a lot less than you would need to if you need a Gillette Fusion or one of those other products with 50+ blades.<br /><br />The grip is excellent as well, and the entire razor can easily detach into 3 parts for cleaning purposes.
  716. Unbelievable quality for under $3! There is no way to tell, from inspecting and handling this razor, that it costs less than $30. The only slight criticism I have is that it puts a bend in the blades along the center (parallel to the sharp edges). This sometimes makes it slightly more difficult to remove used blades. It's really not a big deal though. I just hold the non-sharp ends of the blade with my thumb and forefinger and pull it straight up. It works pretty much perfectly. I use the Gillette 7 O'clock blades.
  717. If you've ever wanted to try double edge razors this would be a great one to start with.   722. Although the product description claims the handle is metal, mine came with cheap blue plastic handles (I bought two - for the price, hard to argue). The plastic handles don't seem to affect function except to decrease the overall weight of the razor, so the criticism is more aesthetic than anything.<br /><br />Thus far I've found the razor to be an acceptable transition from more \\"modern\\" disposables to the traditional safety razor. It takes a few shaves to develop technique, and I've found the low weight of this particular razor helpful in that regard - you do have to apply a little bit of pressure with your hand to get it to shave properly, which is I think similar to the way most people shave with disposables. I've since gotten an antique safety razor that is much heavier and thus requires far less pressure. If I'd started there, I suspect I would have cut my face to bits!<br /><br />Look - this razor isn't going to win any awards. It's not attractive, doesn't feel great in the hand, is a bit too small, and is shipped from overseas (will take a long while to arrive). But hey - it's incredibly cheap and fully functional. If you're contemplating giving safety razor wet shaving a try, you can hardly go wrong starting here. You're only out a couple of bucks if you decide it's not for you, and if it works out, you spent a few dollars to get a nice start with a classy new grooming practice.<br /><br />I like it so far, even though I'm still developing my technique. I suspect a really nice shaving set from one of the more expensive, well-known makers is in my future. But I never would have gotten there without this one. If you're looking to start out, I recommend grabbing one or two of these. If you're already familiar with safety razor shaving, get yourself a nicer one than this!

He gave it a shot and sure enough it messed up his whole face. He looked like a boy who had tried out his Dad's razor. He switched the blade and tried again just to make sure it wasn't the blade. Same result. When compared to his other razor that looks almost identical but is a 1954 Gillette, this one belongs in the recycle bin. I bought this one b/c his antique one has just a little rust around the handle. My husband is in the military and has to be clean shaven every day. After getting all cut up and horrible razor burn he had to keep shaving (with his GOOD razor) for the rest of the week and it was so painful for him. Definitely not a good experience.
  728. I ordered this for my husband and it is great! Love the close shave. Great quality product for very little money. It is worth every penny and more!
  729. I didn't expect much for the price, but really this is just an expensive disposable razor. Made of very cheap ill fitting metal parts that deform and fail under the slightest stress.
  730. I read in a shaving blog that this razor was unbeatable for the money and that is possibly true, but It arrived bent and I wasn't able to get it true again. It also rusted quickly in the humidity of my bathroom. It's a roll of the dice but if you get one that isn't bent it might shave well.
  731. Besides it taking a whole month to be delivered, literally on a slow boat from China, it is soooo cheaply made that it's not worth $2. I bought Wilkinson blades but this razor holds the blades to tear up your face. Buy this at the same time you buy a big box of band aids.
  732. Good quality and sturdy. A nice starter DE razor. Has good weight and balance to it. I will probably use this for a long time.
  733. This razor has to be taken apart to clean or to change blades--major pain in the neck. I wasted my time and money in ordering this product. Would not recommend this to ANYONE.
  734. Tired and feed-up with the cost of razors and blades, bought this for less than $3 and since laugh as I pass that isle in stores. I've used this razor for about 4 months now and is without a doubt the best $2.84 I have ever spent. It is exactly what i expected, no frills, blade stays secure and easy to hold with good weight. This purchase is only rivaled by the 100 double edge blades I bought for around $11.....I'm estimating 4 to 5 years worth. Between the two, it puts a smile on face and I laugh out loud every time I walk by that isle in the store.
  735. Item was similar but not the correct razor. Once it got here after weeks of shipping it was already rusting.

  737. As advertised excellent for travel
  738. I bought this because of the hype lately on why use the 3 blade razor. We end up spending so much more and so I had to try it out. The price is great and it works fine on a wet shave. I haven't had any issues with the sharpness of the blade and make sure it is kept clean. The blades ARE CHEAP anywhere and so you can always have a good edge on the razor when you feel it is needed.
  739. After reading some of the other reviews I was wondering what I might get in the mail. Some said there's was lightweight and plastic-y, others talked about the screw on the bottom, while still others talked about the heft of the one-piece handle...<br /><br />Well, I ordered mine from Imports247 in Hong Kong, and while mine does not look exactly like the photo, I find it an exceptional deal and fine quality even without considering the price. The knurling of the handle is very slightly different from the photo, and the very top of the razor (I dunno, &#34;retainer?&#34;) is one smooth dome - not stepped toward the edge. Mine is heavy, solid, and the handle is one piece. Feels too dense to be &#34;pot metal&#34; (usually cast zinc), but whatever it is it's solid feeling. The design does bend the blade to a slight angle, which I find comfortable.<br /><br />The one thing I'd say which might be ever so slightly negative is that the included blade wasn't very good at all, so it might make someone think that safety razors are not as sharp as, say, a bic single blade disposable, whereas that's not generally the case. But, hey, for less than three bucks, I can't really ding a star for that! I ended up ordering some Astra blades from Amazon, and they are far superior.<br /><br />Overall, I'd absolutely recommend this to someone wanting to try a safety razor for all the various reasons (comfort, cost, environmental impact, space, retro-cool factor, etc.).
  740. Well, I ordered two of these razors and one of them arrived broken. I figured one or both would arive broken considering they were just packed in a plastic bag (No box). The bag was tore open a little and since they come shipped from China I guess that should be expected. I tried out the one good razor and it did not work for me. I ended up going back to my multi blade razors because they work better on my face. Maybe I should give a better safety razor another chance.
  741. Works great, easy to clean, nothing better in my book. I would recommend this to everybody. And replacing the blades is just as simple.
  742. This safety razor is perfect for beginners. I wasn't completely sold on the idea of a safety razor, and I didn't want to spend upwards of 50$ on something I wasn't sure I was going to like. At under five dollars this razor is great for testing out the waters to see if double edge razors are something you will like. Honestly it's not that bad of a razor, the only thing I can see wrong with mine is the blade comes out of one side farther than the other. This can be a little annoying because it feels like one side is more aggressive than the other, and I find myself changing the angle at which I hold the razor depending on which side I'm using. At times it can also feel a little slippery. Other than that I have no complaints. I have been able to get the closest shave I've ever had with this razor. I think even if I end up upgrading to something nicer I will still use this as a travel razor or something. I don't think I will upgrade for a while though because there is really nothing wrong with this razor other than what I mentioned earlier. I would highly recommend this razor to anyone wanting to try out a safety razor.

  792. I ordered the DE razor and some blades on Jan. 27. Just as I was about to click the button to complete the order, I noticed that shipping info came on the screen. I didn't pay too much attention to it, but I should have. It said the delivery would occur between February 27 and March -- for the order placed on Jan. 27. I thought that long a delivery time was a little odd, but whenever I have ordered from Amazon in the past, the delivery was always ahead of schedule.<br /><br />Well, it is March 7 and I have the blades (which came from Thailand), but no razor yet. I can only assume that when I ordered on Jan. 27, the manufacturer had to go to Outer Mongolia, find someone to travel by mule to the most remote spot in Mongolia, use their hands to dig the metal out of the ground, then search for a few days for a one-armed blacksmith to beat the metal into razor blades, and after a couple weeks of refinement put the blades and razor on a mule headed for the coast. Then after getting to the coast, someone put the blades and razor onto a balsa raft similar in construction to Thor Heyerdahl's 1947 Kon-Tiki, and then ship the order, against the prevailing currents, across the Pacific to America. Once the raft got to the West Coast, someone loaded the razor and blades onto the backs of some ants for the voyage from the West Coast to my home in Austin, Texas.<br /><br />Like I said, got the blades but no razor yet.<br /><br />Be sure you are okay with the shipping when you consider an order such as this.
  793. I purchased this razor after seeing my Pawn Star hero advertise a similar safety razor on TV. Not wanting to invest much, I purchased this razor. I used it for the first time yesterday, and I am SO impressed. I got a clean shave, and it doesn't get clogged like multi-blade razors (as of last night, I'm retiring my five-blade Schick), so that sped up my shave time dramatically. To test the product out, I shaved underarms, legs and bikini area (was nervous about that!)<br /><br />This might be TMI, but I had on my &#34;winter growth&#34; - all hair was about 1/4&#34; to 1&#34; long. I did not trim before hand, and this razor took the hair away like a champ, without having to go over and over the same spot.<br /><br />The only detractor is that the grip is a little slippery for women's shaving (lots of skin area, we're usually in the bath or shower with lotions or shave cream everywhere). However, I can solve this by wrapping a rubber band around the grip.<br /><br />I am very confused why anyone &#34;improved&#34; on this design with plastic muti-blade razors. By fat the closest, fastest, most economical and eco-friendly shave I've ever had. TOTAL CONVERT!!

There is a learning curve, and you will cut your neck. I could see somebody using this every day with no problems. After a month with this, I found a mint 1960's Gillette butterfly type so I can easily rinse it while I shave in the shower. I bought a box of 100 Astra Double Edge Safety Razors.   822. I own numerous more expensive double-edge razors (Merkur, Jagger, Parker, Feather by Jatai, and others), and amazingly enough, this cheap little guy can compete with any of them. Seriously, this thing performs just as well as razors that cost four or five times as much money. And its all-metal construction gives it a nice solid heft and feel, along with plenty of \\"old school\\" appeal for those of us who harbor nostalgic feelings for those shiny metal razors we watched our fathers or grandfathers use.<br /><br />I've been giving these as gifts to friends, as a low-cost way of letting them test-drive this old-school method of shaving. So if you're interested in giving double-edge shaving a try, but are hesitant to shell out thirty bucks or more, you really can't go wrong with this. It might be all you ever need.

I did not like the razor blade that comes with it, the blade was very irritating to my skin. Purchased some feather blades and now everything is &#34;hunky dory&#34;. Update October 8, 2015: Since I bought the Silver Tone razor I have moved on to the Edwin Jagger DE89BL and the Merkur 34C razors. The quality of the Edwin Jagger and Merkur is far superior to the Silver Tone. The Edwin Jagger and Merkur 34c razors are not very aggressive but provide a very close shave. For my face, I give the Merkur 34c a slight edge but you cant go wrong with either one. Also, for me, both razors work great with Feather blades or Astra Superior Platinum blades.

  850. Bought one, and have used it for over a year without a hitch. Then I bought 2 more. One for my father, one for travel. Took over 6 weeks to deliver, and received a torn package with only one head and two disposable razors. Contacted seller, whom never responded after two weeks and I had to get refunded from Amazon. Total pain in the rear for only a $7 refund. If you get one that is actually intact, it's a nice razor that is worth the wait. Don't expect all stainless steel. It's steel coated copper (as I've noticed after the undersides that hold the razor itself have slightly worn away).
  851. Bought one of these and found them acceptable enough that I ordered one for my son recently as he wanted a new razor instead of cleaning up a used Gillette. As said ok for the money and will make a good travel razor but for home use I still prefer my vintage Gillette's.
  852. Ive been meaning to swich to wetshaving for a little over a month now and was hesitant because of the \\"high\\" start up costs for a brand name razor. Well, I found this one for 7 bucks, read some convincing reviews and bought it... If I don't like the experience I'm out $7, no biggie.<br /><br />Well, I haven't even started wetshaving properly yet -I used regular shaving cream for the first use- and it's a huge step up from a Fusion already. With the included blade!! A \\"Rimei\\" blade -Chinese, I'm assuming- So i would recommend this razor EVEN if you dont want to venture into wetshaving 100%.<br /><br />My biggest fear trying this \\"new\\" style of razor/shaving was cutting myself due to improper handling but once I had it in my hand and put it to my face it was very intuitive AND it's a lot safer than I thought... I did watch some videos and read some articles tho, so that night've helped subconciously but I feel those \\"aids\\" make it seem harder than what it really is. I don't think one can cut oneself unless you mean it because the blades protrude only so much -and evenly on both sides- unlike someone said on a review, however, there is blade sticking out so be careful AS I WAS; i.e. respect the blade.<br /><br />I miss some spots that I wouldn't have normally missed with a Mach 3, fusion, etc. but I think it's just a matter of getting used to the new razor and surprisingly it was a very close shave, closer that MC razors. I was surprised because I've read that I would take a while for beginners to get a close shave.<br /><br />After I was done shaving, my face felt so much better than when shaving with a multi cartridge razor that I can't even put it in words.... Well, if you drive stick you might get this, imagine you're driving a car with a bad/worn clutch. Well, this razor feels like shifting after replacing the clutch on said car, whereas the bad clutch was a fusion, get it? It feels so good after shaving that it's like you haven't shaved. It also feels like you don't need aftershave -but you do, lol.<br /><br />The razor itself is very well made, it feels good in one's hand, it's pleasing to the eye and considering the brand name de razor prices, it's a steal. The blade it came with was very good to my face and Im only hoping the derby blades I ordered are as good as this blade is.<br /><br />I will update the review once I use it with wetshaving soap and brush.
  853. I am a new user to double edge razors & this is my first double edge shaver. It is hard to distinguished between the razor & the blade due to the razors curved top & blade guard so this has resulted in cuts or hair not being shaved at all. The construction of the unit is steady.

However it ended up breaking after 6 months. The screw part ended up being stripped and somewhat rusted. I'll admit I wasn't as careful with this unit as I should have been which probably contributed to its quick demise. If you are looking for a good cheap start this is a good place but don't expect it to last forever.
  857. So like allot of people getting into DE shaving I used a cartridge razor with 5 blades and had to pay $20 just for a blade or two. I have been very happy with the investment, worth every penny, I may cut my self a little more but I am getting better at avoiding it. So would happy pay this again for it and even turned a few people over to the idea of trying them selves.   890. I am 65 years old and noted these razors are making a comeback with the young shavers. I recommend this one. It has nice heft and the handle is long enough to get the right angle for shaving. None of these razors will work if you have the end of the handle near your skin. You need about a thirty five to forty five degree angle. Just try it and with a new blade you can feel the &#34;baby smooth&#34; skin where you shaved.<br />Getting back to the razor, it is simple and has no moving parts. Some of the ones in the seventies had a knob you turn and the doors open allowing you to change the razor. I have seen these for sale now on line but I don't recommend them because it just something to go bad. I have only had mine three months and it showing some surface rust internally. The razor still looks great and I don't think this problem will require replacement any time soon.<br />So if you are tired of getting ripped off with multi-blade disposables and filling the landfill with plastic try this razor. Depending on the coarseness of your beard you do need to change the blades up to once a week.

  896. I was so happy when i received this razor. I bought myself a brush, and using the conditioner and this razor i had my first shave. I was slow because i wanted to get the technique down. It was the worst shave ive ever gotten. I went over my neck (with the grain) and it immediately went red and i had tons of little cuts. I thought, maybe it was bad technique? So i kept shaving with this razor every other day for about 4 weeks. After 2 weeks my razor burn was awful. So i decided to buy some CO Bigelow and a shaving brush to help. Sadly it didnt. After 4 weeks i have the worst razor burn of my life. Im extremely frustrated with this razor. Ive tried two different brands of razor blade as well, and still couldnt get it right. Then i noticed that the head was bent ever so slightly on both sides that hold the razor. Maybe that is whats making it so bad? Anyways, i decided to buy a Merkur and see if thats the case. I'd say stay away from this razor, but i have an EXTREMELY sensitive neck. So maybe it will work better for you. Good Luck!!

  908. Most reviews on DE razors and blades seem to be more about how wonderful DE shaving is than the product itself. While this was my first DE and I love it, it also has a few shortcomings.<br /><br />First off, if you want to try out DE shaving but don't want to invest much money, don't hesitate: buy this razor! It will change your shaving routine from a chore to a pleasure.<br /><br />That said, compared to a more expensive handle, I find this one a little light--which means you need to put a little pressure on it to get a close shave. The down side to this is that it can lead to a bit of irritation, though still much less than cartridge shaving. Also, although it is a great value for this price point, it does feel and look like the materials are on the cheaper side--when compared to a Parker or Merkur, this doesn't have that classic shine that you might expect from a DE razor. Finally, the opening mechanism (which is common even on base-level razor that costs three times as much) requires a little more work than is ideal given that you'll be changing blades every few days or so.<br /><br />Overall, this is a great first double-edged razor, or a great travel razor for the experienced shaver. If you want to dive in head first, I recommend getting a long-handled Parker or Merkur with a butterfly open. If you want to test the waters a little first, buy this razor!
  909. I have always had trouble paying for razors and never feeling like I get my moneys worth. Thanks to this product, I can say that has changed! As long as you keep a fresh blade on this, you will be loving it. The price of shaving is now my favorite part. How comfortable can dragging a razor across your face really get? Right now I am using &#34;Derby Extra&#34; blades and am pleased.<br /><br />The construction of this is solid. I don't think I will be needing another anytime soon, which is a good thing.

  943. While this is not the \\"best\\" razor, it can work very well. I swapped back to a DE razor from disposables three years ago, and I must admit there is a learning curve. There are a few tutorials on line that may help. I now shave after my shower is complete with soap in a mug (I use Dove) and a brush, finishing up with a splash of Witch Hazel. For me it changed shaving from a required chore to a relaxing ritual. I have gone though a couple cheap razors before I got to this one, each one requiring an adjustment to technique. I must say I like this one allot, especially for the money.<br />I have been thinking about what to do with the hollow handle that is accessible by unscrewing the end piece. Maybe I'll add some weights inside to fiddle with the feel of the razor or just glue it in place like some have said.<br /><br />Update 4/24/13:After using this razor several times I am very pleased with it. While it does not shave quite as close as other cheap DE razors (with the same brand of blades) I have used, it does shave more comfortably with less cuts and abrasion. So the net difference is for slightly more whiskers after 48 hours (no noticeable difference after 24 hours) I have less cuts and irritation, a fair trade I say, for &lt; $6.00 with two day shipping. Now if you wish to spend less and are willing to be patient, I found the same razor elsewhere on Amazon less than half the price. Look for \\"SODIAL- Silver Tone Double Edge Blade Razor Shaver w Nonslip Metal Handle\\" for $2.29 and free shipping from Hong Kong. I ordered one and got it two weeks later, and it was the exact same razor as the one I got from this ad...so I ordered four more , for travel, spares, leaving at relatives, etc.
  944. This was purchased for 2 young men that were tired of trying to get a great shave with the 5 blade rip off shavers of today. They are using these razors and say that they get a better shave. I have used these for years and love it
  945. Ok I paid less than 3 bucks for someone to MAKE this cool looking metal shaver and then SHIP it from CHINA!<br /><br />Mine came with on of the sides on the top bent during the shipping process I assume cause it was in an envelope rather than a box but I bent it back the correct way and it works great. They should definitely ship it in a box though.<br /><br />Really can't complain for 3 bucks but probably will go with a Edwin Jagger for about 30 bucks to get a real quality product.
  946. Though it looks similar, this razor isn't anything like the one I learned to shave with almost seventy years ago. I started at about age 6 and even though these were called safety razors back then, I went to school the next day with several bandaids on my face. If you buy one of these razors from China, do your face a favor and throw out the blade that comes with the razor. Fortunately I had bought a 10 pk of generic blades made in Israel before my razor arrived. I tried the included blade first and, OUCH! It would pull the hairs out before it would cut them. I got through the first shave unscathed with one of the Israeli blades but on my second attempt I got through the epidermis and part way into the dermis on the ridge of my cheek near the upper lip. Stopping the bleeding for someone taking aspirin twice a day takes some doing. If you're on Coumadin, you may want to stick to electric shaving. Anyway, I survived that and got through a couple more adventures since without a nick. But you really have to be aware that this is a bit like performing surgery with a steak knife. Exercise patience and use a delicate touch. If you rush it, you will likely be bloodied. Perhaps the most irksome feature of this model is that the head of this razor must be removed and separated into two parts to remove the blade for cleaning. I surely regret disposing of my old Gilette safety razor. Now I have nothing to compare with. But, paying about 27 cents per blade is way cheaper than the ever escalating prices being charged for the latest umpteen edge blades and disposables. Good ruck.
  947. I love the product and the delivery was on time. I'll recommended this seller as a excellent seller. I love, love, this product although it was shipped from the other side of the world, but when I received it I was very excited to use it.
  948. I have had this razor now for almost a year, and still use it to this day. I have not upgraded, or replaced the original I purchased.<br /><br />This is not a Merkur. This is the cheap knock off product of it. This little guy has however held up, and has well surpassed its value!<br /><br />I would buy this again before spending triple to quadruple the amount on a main market brand double edged razor, even if it broke on me tomorrow.<br /><br />I purchased Derby razor blades to go in this (100 of them), and they fit like any other blade would.<br /><br />If your getting into wet shaving, need a travel shaver, or just want a cheap shaver to keep around for guests, get this one and there will be no turning back.

  958. I bought this razor to try out double-edge shaving and I've been using it for about a month with Astra blades. Astra blades are known to be on the mild side, and I believe this razor is not very aggressive. If you have a heavy, thick, coarse beard like me then do not go with this combination. I constantly get ingrown hairs and irritation because the shave is too mild and it tugs at my beard. I haven't tried any other blades yet, but I've read that Feather blades will cut anything, so they might be a better choice for this razor.<br /><br />Since this is my first DE razor I can't say how it compares to others, but I will say that it seems to be made well. The only issue I found is that the blade is not automatically centered in the head, so if you see one side of the blade exposed more than the other then just force it to center while you tighten the head. It's not a big issue if you know to look out for it.<br /><br />I'll give this one 4 stars for the value. It served its purpose of getting me in to DE shaving, but if I were to start over again I'd go straight for a more aggressive razor.
  959. I'm one of those people who hates spending money on myself. I was tired of switching out razors in hubby's Edwin Jagger De86bl, so I purchased this based on reviews and the low price. I shaved my legs using the same soap, razor blade, and brush that I always used. After three cuts, and burning skin, I stopped before completing the job. The weight and balance of this razor is completely wrong. With the Edwin Jabber I can't feel that the blade is doing anything, and it simply glides over my skin. This hurt and irritated my skin, and I was petrified of cutting myself. Needless to say, I just ordered an ivory handled Edwin Jagger to match hubby's ebony handled model. This was a complete waste of money, and the quality and usability was horrible. I actually prefer the razors that hotels hand out as freebies. Shaving with the Edwin Jagger is comfortable and provides a safe and irritation free shave. If I had to shave with this, I'd choose to never shave again! You get what you pay for.
  960. When i got this razor, i was impressed at how it looked. it looked decent made and looked like it would last a while. but that's where it ended. as far as cutting, it didn't. the blade was to far behind the guard for my taste and it angled down when the head was tightened. the only way i could use it was if i wouldn't tighten the head down, meaning it would spin freely, then it would cut poorly, but was dangerous cause it swiveled.i like mine with a lot of blade sticking out and my previous razor, which i paid 5.88 for worked great for a few years til it broke, and the model was no longer sold. disgusted i gave up on it and set it aside. a few days later, i got the idea to modify it. it was only 3 dollars and a half, so if i screwed up, i wasn't out much and i didn't plan on ever using it again, only in a pinch situation would i use it. so i got the idea, guard to long? what guard?. as you guess, i took some pliers and with a little bending, popped both guards complete off, and to my suprise, now i got as much blade as i want to shave with, and shave with it i do. now it cuts good like my old one. please note, do not try this if you have little experience with these razors. i have used these for years, so i know what to do with them so i'm not afraid of them. i've used it now about 5 times and it cuts just as good as my old one and i've had 0, yes, ZERO nicks or cuts, i docked it a star cause of the slow shipping. took almost, a few days shy of a month to get. i know coming from china would have been slow, but i'm convinced i could row a boat myself over and get it faster. i plan on buying a few more today, so in hopes it comes before i die of old age and i will put them up in storage in my dresser drawer incase i need another one, or in case the price may go up higher.
  961. Bottom line, I HATE buying disposable razors. They are just ridiculously expensive.<br /><br />This handle is very easy to use, clean, and I have had great results shaving with it. It does take a little patience when using a single blade, but in my opinion is well worth the cost.
  962. Pro's:<br />The weight, build, and finish was better than I anticipated. I expected some scrawny razor made of lightweight plastic with a cheap silver tone finish but that wasn't the case. The weight is sufficient to allow me to glide the blade against my face without having to apply too much pressure.<br /><br />Cons:<br />Blade replacement is somewhat of a hassle and definitely not as advertised in the description. The bottom screw is completely superficial. It is not connected to the razor head and serves no function. I have no idea why they would add this screw other than to mislead buyers into thinking it resembles the design of other, more expensive, safety razor blades which actually do have easier, safer, blade replacement and blade adjustment features.<br /><br />To replace the razor you have to unscrew the head from the top, which then falls apart into 4 pieces (the handle, 2 pieces of the head, and the razor itself). You can definitely cut yourself if you're not paying attention or accustomed to the process. I can definitely understand if others would rather pay more to avoid this hassle. That's really based on individual preference.<br /><br />The product also came in a really cheap package without any English text but I suppose that's to be expected at this price point. In fact, I'd probably be more upset if the same product cost more because it came in a flashy package.<br /><br />PLEASE NOTE:<br />The design is similar to the Merkur Progress as the blade will lock in at an angle and will not rest perfectly perpendicular to the handle. Since the head is bending the blade, you can take a much more shallow angle with each stroke. I personally found this more comfortable. Do not take the same angle with this as you would other perpendicular resting DE razor blades. I think this may have attributed to some of the negative reviews where some people got cuts or razor-burn as opposed to when they shaved with other name brand safety razors.<br /><br />Judgement: As someone who is relatively new to shaving with a safety razor, I found this a great value purchase. It wasn't perfect but it was half the cost of other brand names and saving cash was the main reason I got into safety razors in the first place. I get a closer, therapeutic shaving experience with this product and can now avoid spending on costly proprietary multi-blade cartridges.

I have only used the Gillette 7 O'clock super platinum's. The blades don't tug or irritate my skin when going with the grain, but if I try to get a closer shave and go across or against the grain I feel some tugging and I usually get light irritation (even with a good shaving soap and brush, proraso pre-shave cream, and aftershave). I would definitely suggest a sample pack of blades if you are just getting started with safety razors, because blades that work well for other people or in different models might not as well for you.<br /><br />Lastly, does anyone have suggestions on what blades might work well with this razor? I just got a pack of Feathers that I am going to try next shave and see how they compare with the Gillette 7 O'clock super platinum's.

The result is tugging of the whiskers, scraping of the skin, and a poor shave. Extra care must be taken to avoid cuts. I bought this hoping for a convenient travel razor, but mostly out of curiosity. With that curiosity sated, I'll go back to my heavy, perfectly-fitting English antique, which has served me well for 35 years, and my father for 30 years before that.   1013. I've been using disposable razors for the past 30 years. Although the costs have been getting insanely high, my main objection has been that I kept finding bargain-priced razors which were virtually worthless.<br /><br />Old fashioned strait-edge razors look terrifing to me, and also I don't know much about stropping-belts, so a safety-razor looked like my best bet.<br /><br />After a bit of research, here at Amazon, I found that I could get 100 blades for around $7. What a cost difference compared to disposables!<br />I went with the Derby brand blades, which I have not yet tested, because of their excellent price and consistently favorable reviews.<br /><br />As for the razor itself, I can't say I'm very impressed. It came in a small blister-pack, labeled entirely in Chinese. It's chrome plated metal and has a cheap, almost gaudy look to it. The size and length are about what I remember from past safety-razors.<br /><br />I was completely baffled by how one loads the blades into it. My old safety-razor had a small section at the handles bottom, that turned (like a womans lipstick), and opened the blade housing. This razor uses a simpler arrangement. You unscrew the HEAD of the razor, which disassembles it, and load it rather like a breach-loading gun. A bit crude, but effective. It came with one blade and I was dismayed to see it protruding, just slightly, at the ends. I don't know if thats a problem with the included blade or whether it could cause cuts. I tried the razor out, being careful around the ends and did not cut myself, and given that it shaves just fine, it may not be an issue.<br />In conclusion, I think this razor will do for now and might even turn out to be a solid investment.<br /><br />One things sure, at about 7 cents a blade, my disposable razor days are over.<br /><br />A quick update: I have tested the Derby brand blades and found them perfectly fine. The box has odd markings including Arabic and what I take to be some Nordic language.<br />The box indicates the blades are made in Turkey. Huh, that's a first for me. I'm old enough to remember when Made In Japan was kind of exotic.<br />I have also subsequently learned that the razors which open up are called Butterfly razors. I may still go with one later. As for the Silver Tone, it shaves fine but I'm used to the square handles of disposable razors. These metal safety-razors have handles that are round. This makes it tricky to tell (by feel alone), if the razors head is facing me at the correct angle. A square profile would be better, I believe. Just a small quibble and I still think this razor is a good value.he box indicates the blades are made in Turkey. Huh, that's a first for me. I'm old enough to remember when Made In Japan was kind of exotic.<br />I have also subsequently learned that the razors which open up are called Butterfly razors. I may still go with one later. As for the Silver Tone, it shaves fine but I'm used to the square handles of disposable razors. These metal safety-razors have handles that are round. This makes it tricky to tell (by feel alone), if the razors head is facing me at the correct angle. A square profile would be better, I believe. Just a small quibble and I still think this razor is a good value.

  1018. I bought this product knowing that it was made in China. With many recent press reports of lead being found in products from China, I was concerned about dragging it across my face on a nearly-daily basis. I bought a simple at-home test for lead from the hardware store, and tested the cutting edge. The test returned a negative result for lead, this product is safe.<br /><br />As a whole, I am happy with it as a first DE razor as well, it provides a very close shave without ANY nicks or razor burns.
  1019. Fantastic quality and polishing. The metal surfaces of the razor are extremely smooth, the chrome finish shines and it has a very nice heft to it. I hope the finish holds up as I continue to use the item, but I'm optimistic.<br /><br />There are a lot of tutorials and tips out there on how to use a safety razor, and a lot of them include talk about needing a bristle brush and fancy shaving soap or something. However, by the time I had this razor in my hand I just started my usual shaving routine with my usual spray can shaving cream, and I had a very nice shave! A helpful tip I heard somewhere was not to leave it for very long under hot water, since it's solid metal and holds heat easily. Anyway, this is an easy thing that I think I'll be doing for a while.<br /><br />The included blade is nice, and I am looking forward to being able to try out different blades and see what's out there. They all seem really affordable on Amazon, and it looks like even Walgreens has a pack for a few bucks.<br /><br />Shipping from Hong Kong took a couple weeks but it made it several days earlier than Amazon estimated.<br /><br />EDIT: Three months later, and the chrome finish is still PERFECT. This is a very high quality product at a shockingly low price. I'd love to buy another one but...it looks like I won't have to for a long time!

  1058. Not much to say that hasn't already been said. This razor is very high quality, even if it were $25, but it's not, it's under $3.00 with free shipping. I've been using this razor now for a year as my first ever experience with a safety razor. I went cold turkey and started using this and never went back to a Gillette cartridge Mach 3 again. What finally made me go for it, was that I turned 35 (now 36) and wanted to reconnect with what my father and grandfather must have experienced, only to find that I had a similar experience as another reviewer on here. Bumps and irritation go away pretty soon, so do ingrown hairs. If you do it right and don't buy all of this silly expensive cream and bowl and shave brush, but just use Barbasol shaving cream and an aftershave balm, you will find it's a much cleaner and comfortable shave, just as fast, practical and farrrrr cheaper to shave with a safety razor. Since I've bought this first one, I have bought a second that cost more and trust me, this is a good one.<br /><br />Parts are solid and polished. No visible rust or corrosion. Parts still fit together nicely (it's a three piece razor).<br /><br />Well balanced, and a perfectly shave angle. Not too mild, not too aggressive.<br /><br />If I were to add one con, I would say that I only wish this came in a kit, as since the razor is so cheap and so nice, I bet for 4 times the price, they could have made a kit that included the razor, a travel holder and a counter stand!!<br /><br />:-)<br /><br />Thank you!!

  1107. I first shaved with a razor similar to this. Somewhere in time I think it was Bic that invented the disposable razor. Then there were many more brands. They were inexpensive and may have been the demise of the safety razor. Then electric razors became affordable. Over the years the cost of disposable razors has increased drastically. Also, I found that most days I needed to at least touch up where the stubble had appeared. During a brief period stubble was a fashion statement but in my occupation fashion statements were not tolerated. Therefore, the twice a day shave was invented.<br />Over time they came out with two blades which wasn't bad. Then three! I'm sure if I missed four or if it never happened. Then five! Wow! What a terrible shave. It hurt like hell, too! I felt like my face was being pulled off and not the whiskers.<br />Then I saw this razor and I thought that it would be nice to try one of these again. I used this to shave yesterday morning. A few little nicks but nothing serious. The nearby septic pencil was not needed and a little splash of aftershave, a masculine sting of years gone by and I looked as clean as if I just stepped from a barbershop. About sixteen hours later and I still feel smooth. I am thinking that I may not have to shave tomorrow!
  1108. I thought it was taking a slow boat from China, but once it got started it made very good time. It got here about three weeks early. Some have commented on how short the handle is, it may be a little short. I have a tendency to choke up anyway so not an issue. Some have commented they got butchered, I don't know that I had one knick with it the four or five times I used it. It is in my travel bag. The blade may not be as sharp as some but I will use it until it is totally dull and then put in a Wilkenson and carry on. It is definitely light-weight which is fine. The razor comes in four pieces, which means that you can cut yourself replacing the blade. This can be worked around, some blades are in a dispenser, which means you won't be in too much danger. The blades I will be using are wrapped in two layers of paper so I will use the paper to insulate the blade. The only drawback is the nub/button on the bottom of the handle, it has a tendency to come loose. I will either crimp the threads with a pair of pliers or put a dab of glue on it to solve the problem. It does not affect the use of the razor. It fits nicely in a travel soap container with my shave brush and a pack of blades to keep it company.<br /><br />25 Oct -- Still ticking and doing fine. I have used it probably 30 times, changed the blade with no issues. Have yet to nick myself. Mostly it is doing better than my Gillette vintage adjustable, I may need to work on the adjustments a little more. $3, $15, or $90, just as good as far as I am concerned.

  1116. This razor has good weight and works well, but it could be a little bit bigger. One thing I did not know before buying and wish I knew beforehand is that it does not have a butterfly door top that opens to change blades as other safety razors do, the top just unscrews and separates into three pieces(bottom holder, top closure and blade), then you put the blade in. For the price, it's a great way to find out if you like shaving with a safety razor.
  1117. I purchased a few of these since they were so cheap. One for me, one for my grandfather. They are good razors, all in all. Sure they're cheap and made in China, but they are fairly solid and weigh enough to be sturdy and comfortable to hold. It's all metal and made the same way as any that are in the $15-$50 range, at least. The angle is perfectly fine and there isn't anything fancy to bend or break. It's just your standard, basic DE razor. Really, I don't know why you wouldn't pick this one over a more expensive razor of the same design. Really, the blade is where it matters the most. The shaver itself isn't going to irritate or not irritate you, it is all in the blade you choose, and this is where the only drawback lies; the blade that comes with this particular shaver is absolutely horrendous. It has Chinese writing on it, so I am unsure of the brand as I can not read anything that is not English, but I do know it is more capable of cutting my skin than it is at cutting my hair. I replaced this blade after my first spell of what can only be described as total skin annihilation, and everything was completely fine. Once you find a blade style/brand that is right for you, you will have no problems with this shaver. If you put this is a Merkur package and sold it for $50, it would have near perfect reviews. It's one of those &#34;I know it's cheap so that means it is bad&#34; deals, in my opinion, because I have had just as many clean, BBS shaves with this as I have with any other expensive DE shaver. Again, it almost wholly lies in the blade you choose. I recommend this shaver, especially for beginners just getting in to wet shaving or people looking for something to throw something cheap into their shave kit. Just don't touch the razor it comes with and buy a sample pack of them at the same time you order this, because you need to try as many brands as possible to find what is right for you and your skin type.

  1125. I am a bit of a straight-razor enthusiast myself, but I purchased a few of these as christmas gifts for guys that I knew would appreciate it. I end up having to use at least 2 or 3 passes to get what I want, but it's still less time consuming than my straight.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- Shipping speed is slow, a couple weeks out, just plan ahead.<br />- Blades it came with were definitely sub-par, I'm using several different types and they're all an improvement.<br />- The packaging it came in was disappointing, but on par for the price. i removed it from this to give as a gift.<br />- Almost too mild in my opinion. It takes some serious work to trim a beard down, then becomes clogged with hair.<br /><br />Overall: great deal, and honestly made a great gift. The one that I kept will be staying around until I find something nice and vintage.

  1137. I went through 3-head and foil electrics, Mach 3s, Bic Sensitives, Bic Metals, and Parker straight razors before landing on this baby; and I haven't looked back. As a fair-skinned African-American male, I wanted a razor that cut effectively and didn't drag, while having replacement blades that were affordable. This little guy plus 100 blades can be had for less than $10 now, and the performance is excellent. The metal handle screws off to allow replacement of the blades, and the guides help align the blade evenly and effectively. The safety guard has performed well, too; no nicks after a two weeks of daily use. Highly recommended; strong buy.
  1138. I've used another double-edge razor for a few years now (Parker 91R). Consequently, the blade protrudes much further than with my other razor. It has a nice heft to it and feels like it'll take a beating without breaking. Threads are nice and smooth and the top section is well formed and sturdy.<br /><br />My only gripe with it was the postage, I ordered it July 7 and it was estimated to be delivered between July 22-31, I received it August 9th, so a little over a month from ordering. But I'm from Australia so that might have had an impact on the time.<br /><br />If you're thinking of trying a safety razor, it's $3AUD with postage, just buy it! But expect to wait a little while for it to turn up. And buy some decent blades and go with it.

  1163. This is a pretty excellent product for how cheap it is. The handle is solid, and the whole thing has a nice weight to it. After using it for over a year, there's no chipping away of a metal coating, and barely any rusting (just a bit around the screws inside the head). I dropped it once and the head bent a bit, and that side of the razor began cutting me because the blade angle changed. I was able to bend it back and, after replacing the blade, it worked perfectly. It is a bit scary to take apart, but that is the same with any safety razor. I think this is an excellent introductory product if you're thinking about switching to safety razors.

I then graduated to a disposable straight razor with razor blades.<br /><br />The straight razor is still the closest shave I've had to date, yet I have a fiancee that loves to move around me, distract me, or jostle me when shaving (She is used to disposable razors so it probably doesn't come to mind that I'm shaving with an open blade that could slice my throat wide open), which has resulted in bloodshed (I laid-open my jaw last time I was jostled, got a nice scar from it too). Hense the reason behind me purchasing this Safety Razor.<br /><br />Its craftsmanship is much better than I anticipated. I ended up ordering Lord blades and those are excellent for my skin and facial hair type - no tugging. The blades are thinner than I'm used to handling but as a whole, the razor has enough heft to it to easily remove facial hair. NEVER DRAG or APPLY PRESSURE. This is not an aggressive shaver (the blade doesn't protrude very far from the safety head) but enough that it can open up bumps, acne, or in-grown hairs but after my first shave, not so much as a scratch.<br /><br />Use a Badger Bristle Shaving brush, a glycerin-based shaving soap (English soaps are preferred - Lavendar) and a low to non-alcohol based aftershave (Sandalwood) for best results .<br /><br />Swagg Supernatural,<br /><br />D. Magic J. Slimm

  1224. I'm a woman who has had a problem for years now: women's razors. I'm a very hirsute woman (to be plolite) and I find ladies' razors pricy; and often they have weird &#34;moisture bars&#34; and such added on to the head, causing irritation and discomfort on the legs. For the past four years I've been using men's razors (with a puck-style shaving soap and brush) and while the irritation is down, I still get ingrown hairs and nicks from the triple-blade head getting clogged up.<br /><br />My grandfather, tired of seeing my pain, suggested a safety razor like the one he's used for fifty years now. I bought this one, thinking if I didn't like it I could throw it away and not have wasted $30+ like with the other razors. It shipped in two weeks from Hong Kong, arriving much earlier than anticipated (razor arrived 13 Dec and it was meant to come in 19 Dec). I shave daily and tonight I shaved with it for the first time before a Christmas party.<br /><br />My leg irritation is GONE. Ingrown hairs are no issue. I got a clean shave, with only a small nick on my thigh from not having it at the right angle. The nick scabbed over much faster than it would have with a normal razor. It's the best shave I've ever had, and now I'm going to trust it with all the hair problems I may have. So menfolk if I trust this razor with my legs and near delicate areas like my knees, ankles, and thighs then you can trust it with your face. You can't go wrong.

It holds the blades nicely and is easy to change them. The handle is just the right length and weight for me.<br /><br />My next one will have an adjustable angle.
  1232. As other user has mentioned the handle is too small. I am okay with small grip handle since it allows be to be more careful and precise when shaving. Gets smudged easily.<br /><br />I would highly recommend to to anyone who is considering this as their first double edged razor. I got this a few weeks ago when I decided to give double edged shaving a try and so far it has worked.<br /><br />Btw, when shaving you have to be very careful as I always end up with minor cuts (I personally would not recommend this to be used for any other place other than the face).
  1233. old fashion to shave is best. less expend money and razor blade easy to in use and clean. look great
  1234. Excellent razor. When I first started shaving when I was 16, I could feel the bumps coming as I shaved, not with this one. I got a clean even shave on my face and head. Love it
  1235. this razor took over two weeks to arrive and it was no good at all. actually we could not get the handle to turn to open and insert the blade. we tried using a wrench and it still did not open.
  1236. This old fashioned razor is a steal at the price it was going for. I've been using the first one for about 2-3 months and my face has never been this smooth. I had really bad irritation after shaves with stupid 5-blade systems. Not only did these multi-blade systems often cut into my skin, I always felt my face stubbly on certain spots and already tender from one pass from a 5-blade razor. This old fashioned razor gets to all the tough spots and doesn't leave my skin irritated.<br /><br />More blades isn't always better, it's better to have one good blade than five blades that either don't cut the stubble off or cut too deep and make people bleed.
  1237. Delivery is a little slow. This is the second order I've placed for this razor and it takes them 3 weeks or so. The quality of the razor is quite high and gives me a really close and cheap shave when I use the dime Russian blades sold on Amazon. I had not had a safety razor in many years, but decided to buy one when I saw the dime Russian blades. Well, I ordered a razor that was about $15 and a second for $7 or $8, and then this one for $3 including shipping. The other 2 are the traditional safety razors where you turn the bottom of the handle a a gate opens at the top. The problem with the traditional razors is that the blade sits flat in the razor. The advantage of this $3 job is that when you screw it back together with the blade in it, the blade is forced to conform to the shape of the head and does not hit your face a a right angle. I highly recommend this razor and the dime Russian blades for a cheap close shave!
  1238. It is good! I am enjoying using it! The razor it comes with isn't the best so be sure to buy a pack!
  1239. as an embroidery operator, mistake embroidery happens more than i want, but this double edge razor works fast and effective to remove this embroidery mistake, try it , it works very well! do need to stock up on razor blade too!

  1242. Great razor but def not what I ordered. It took about a month for it to come from china. I should have figured that for like $4 total. This kinda bothers me since the name of the post included &#34;nonslip metal handle.&#34; The head doesn't disassemble anything like the picture which would be much more convenient. Instead you are left juggling 3 very small pieces (one of which is a wet slippery razor blade) to sufficiently dry the assembly after use. BUT that being said, I got this to get into using a safety razor to shave to save money and get a better shave and both objectives where met. I will get a better razor eventually but I love this style of shaving so I'm happy with the purchase. I did order around Christmas so that may have slowed the international mail but when I bought it the estimated delivery date was like a month in the future--it actually took that long. Hey I got what I paid for even if it's not what I picked out

So this razor is in fact a double edged sword (see what I did there?). Yes you will save money, but you'll get a sub-par shave.<br /><br />I bought Astra blades to use with this. Shaves almost as close as a Mach 3! But that's for another review...

  1261. Product came on time and was pretty much expecting what I paid for, maybe ended up with a better deal than i realize. So, coming from a gillette pro-glide razor this thing is a pain to shave with (I suggest watching youtube videos) but with that being said, keep reading!! Now after you watch the youtube videos and become a little more informed, pretty much you have to take your time with this..I am used to quick shaving in the shower usually when I am running late to work (often haha) I have a decently thick beard. but have learned shave with this before bed and when I wake up im good to go, still a nice clean shave when i wake up.<br /><br /> It can be a little discouraging at first using this because you wont get &#34;as clean&#34; as a shave as you are used to and the first time actually shaved twice to help get most of it. Also you should know I have very sensitive skin and cant use the cheap bic style razors cause they irritate my skin like no other and occasionally the fusion will too but not too bad. This so far, no razor burn and I still just use shave gel cause I didn't buy any shave soaps and to me works just fine.<br /><br /> Depending on how you wear your facial hair, Mine would be considered a extended goatee so I haven't figured out a way yet to kind help shape it with the safety razor, but still working on it. For the mean time I still use my gillette for that little precision trimmer on the back of the blade but hoping to eliminate that soon, since the reason I purchased this razor was to cut down on costs since those fusion blades are super expensive.<br /><br /> Now overall product, will say this is smaller than I expected, I know the measurements are in the description but didn't take the time to whip out my tape measure and compare it to my old razor. The razor overall feels great in the hand and has a solid metal weight to it (does that make sense?) and does not feel like it was made cheap like I was expecting. So far shaved about 4 times withit and it gets easier each time, like I said it is easy to get discouraged and you will cut yourself a lot at first cause it is so easy to do..make sure you have after shave handy!<br /><br /> But what I have learned is that you learn better on one like this because it is easier to control. I would definitely get a pack of blades though, it comes with just one which lasts a few shaves but its not the comfortable to shave with...i read your safe with anything platinum coated but remember for this razor to buy the double sided blades. Overall well worth the money paid for it. This is my first safety razor and figured if I end up sticking with shaving like this I will buy a better one, but to learn on this is perfect.

  1271. I've been looking for a quick, smooth shave with different methods for a while now. I tried disposable razors, but the multi-blade ones didn't seem to do anything, and the cheap single-blade ones were scratchy and wasteful. I tried the Norelco Aquatec razor, which is supposedly one of the best and allows you to wet shave, but it took forever, required charging, and pulled at my skin, and always left a few stray hairs it couldn't get. I never considered straight razors because of the danger.<br /><br />Then I got this, along with a pack of hi-stainless feather blades ( [[ASIN:B001G5FOLI 10 Feather Razor Blades NEW Hi-stainless Double Edge]] ). I've used it twice now, and each time is tied for the best shave of my whole life. You have to be a little more careful than when using a disposable razor because the blade sticks out a little more, but the angle makes it perfect for getting close without scraping too hard or nicking (as long as you shave with even, gentle pressure and always move perpendicular to the blade, like cleaning a window with a squeegee). With the super-sharp feather razor blades, you hardly need to use any pressure at all to shave.<br /><br />The only thing I was worried about is the lead content. This thing is extremely made in China. The packaging is four parts Mandarin and one part Engrish. But another reviewer mentioned that it tested negative for lead, and I believe him. I'll test it myself soon and update my review accordingly. EDIT: No lead found.<br /><br />So what are you waiting for? If you're new to safety razors, order this and a pack of sharp blades right now. You'll be glad you did.
  1272. I was looking for an inexpensive safety razor frame. I chose this because of the high ratings. It is built very cheap.   1273. What a decent razor - it is a solid performer and is a great value for money.<br /><br />I had ordered this razor based not only on the price but also because it had a large percentage of good reviews.There were hardly any quality issues reported (unllike some other razors that had issues with threading etc.).Like many more guys, I felt sick and tired of spending unreasonable amount of money on the multi-blade cartridges-it was not only about the 'amount' of money but also a question of spending 'judiciously'. My contention was - men still used to enjoy the experience of shaving when those multi-bladed razors didn't even exist!! Why do we need them now...just because someone spends tons of money on advertising to prove that those are better and recovers that from us in the form of the price of the razors or cartridges? So, I thought of returning to DE razors (which I liked in teen age but quit because I was carried away by the marketing gimmicks...yes, I was inexperienced then).<br /><br />Well, when it arrived, I gave it a shot with the same 'RiMei' blade that came with the safety razor and my favourite Dr. Bronner's Tea tree and Shikakai shave gel (which works well ONLY with a nice shaving brush).The handle may seem to be smaller to those used to the long-handled cartridge razors.It is fairly long though.<br /><br />The first few strokes created the 'wow' experience. It indeed does a real good cutting job.I would say it is a solid performer and have no complaints against it.I had ordered a sampler pack of blades as well and would try to figure out which blade suits me the best (and that is altogether a subjective thing).I have to say that it didn't feel aggressive on my skin.<br /><br />Once you have this razor, you may or may not go for those $30-$40 kinda razors down the line.<br />I would give this razor an excellent rating.
  1274. Will not buy again, very cheaply made. You get what you pay for.
  1275. I ordered this because (1) when I was using schicks and gillettes mach 3 and mach 5 and mach Infinity etc. I was having serious issues with razor bumps and ingrown hair. It was negatively impacting my skin in a serious way (dark patches and razor bumps).<br /><br />So I gave that up and tried various other products and at one point I even tried some hair removal cream on my face. My hair would come out so hard and so rough that nothing less than a mach 3 would work. Then when even that stopped working I would have to use a mach 4 and then a mach 5 and every time the stubble would become thicker and harsher and I would start getting a shadow earlier and earlier. A lot of people said they were having the same issues so I decided to switch to other options.<br /><br />Then the option that worked for me was single blade razors. They were gentle on the skin and they were cheaper. Initially they didn't work on my ravaged skin but I kept on using them and after a few years (I think) I no longer looked like I had a 5 o clock shadow (at the wrong hour), my skin and hair became softer and easier to shave with the Bic disposable razors.<br /><br />Then someone started bothering me about being not very environmentally conscious so I decided to look this option up because I try to be good. I had seen my father and uncles and grandpa use this so I ordered one. Finding blades for it (by wilkinson at Walmart) was problematic but that is a shame. The blades sell for $1.76 for ten of them which is really cool compared to the insane amount of money I used to pay for the three blades with gillette and schick (which did a worse job than this single blade safety razor). The razor is bulky so I am not giving it all five stars. I am also deducting points for the rarity of the blades (the blades I got from Walmart did not look \\"clean\\" , they were smudgy and had some sort of stain on them).

For less than it was going to cost me to get refills for my existing razor, I decided to give it a try.<br /><br />I couldn't be happier. I recommend that you purchase higher quality blades for it, the one that comes with it will do but is not the best. After 3 weeks of use, I can report that the razor is holding up very well, no rust even though I have a bad habit of putting it away wet.<br /><br />There really isn't much more to say, I highly recommend this razor.
