  1287. I just received this razor in the mail. It is a three piece DE razor. It's heavy, well balanced, and attractive. According to its aggressiveness design, it is a mild safety razor -- as compared to medium aggressive and aggressive razors that have larger gaps and expose more blade -- it has a cutting head that is designed to limit the amount of force that is transferred to the blade's edge. It has a smaller blade gap than aggressive razors exposing a smaller amount of the double-edge blade -- less likely to cut your skin than an aggressive razor. In addition, the design of the safety bar is a wider angle to allow the blade to cut beard growth without making significant contact with the surface of the skin.<br /><br />Mild razors are preferable for many men with very sensitive skin or men with lighter texture beard hair that can easily fit through the small blade gap. Men with thicker beard stubble may dislike a mild razor like this one because they know when they can't feel the blade against their skin that the razor is not cutting enough hair and they may have to go over the same spots many times in order to get a clean shave.<br /><br />I have sensitive skin and lighter texture beard, so this razor works great for me. I shaved this morning with a Van der Hagen glycerin soap (best for sensitive skin), shaving brush, and Kroger generic DE blades (non-Platinum coated Personna blade). The shave was very close, similar to my Gillette Mach 3. For best results, do not press, just let it glide. For those with thicker beards, that want more safety, try this razor using Feather razor blades to add more aggressiveness. Definitely worth buying and save hundreds of dollars a year on Mach 3 cartridges. If you are new to wet shaving, it is one of the manliest rituals you will ever enjoy. The packaging mentions the manufacturer makes precision calipers, and the quality shows, especially with their ISO certification. Like many products sold in the US, it is manufactured in China, shipped from Hong Kong and its package is written in both Mandarin and English. I also just bought a high-end British made Edwin Jagger DE Razor and can't wait to compare the two.
  1288. This is a very clunky, uncomfortable razor to shave with. I gave it a shot but didn't like the feel of it and never felt comfortable with it.
  1289. It is like shaving with a piece of broken glass. It does not shave It rips the beard from my face.
  1290. You may be saying &#34;it's only $3!&#34; but if you buy this you are literally throwing $3 away. It does not shave.<br /><br />That is not to say it shaves poorly, or too aggressively, or is uncomfortable or unwieldy. It does not shave, period. The head design is literally incompatible with even being able to shave. The safety bar sticks so far out and the top cap curves the blade so much, that the blade is not exposed at all. You could run this razor across your face without so much as removing a single millimeter of hair.<br /><br />Take your $3 and find another $7, then combine those to buy yourself a vintage Gillette Tech. It's cheap, plentiful on auction sites, and made to last. Most importantly, it's actually designed correctly so you can shave with it.
  1291. This was my first experience with a safety razor. I chose this handle because I wanted to try it out before I bought one for $50 or more. I was both impressed and disappointed.<br /><br />The Bad:<br />As the description states, the handle is metal, but the top is not. In fact the cheap plastic top started to flake the fake chrome paint after the first use. The blade include wasn't nearly sharp enough. It pull the hair so much, it almost felt like I was tweezing the hairs. A third of the way through my shave, I gave up and finished with a disposable. That had to be the worst shave of my life. After i was done shaving, I had no cuts at all.<br /><br />The Good:<br />I wasn't satified with reviewing the shaver until I tried some quality blades with it. I bought some Astra blades which aren't really high end but still quality blades. As I began to shave, the razor did all the work. I was amazed at how easy it was to shave with a double edge razor, and the results were incredibly smooth. This shaver held the razor firmly and provided the correct spacing to get an excellent shave.<br /><br />In sum, I would buy a quality handle. The quality of this is not impressive. It should last long enough until I can get a quality brand. If you are looking for something cheap to try double edge shaving, this might be a good bet, but it will take over a month to receive it from China. Either way, I'm sold on double edge shaving provided I have a quality handle and quality blades.

  1299. Worked alright. Rusted a bit on the interior. Not stainless steel.
  1300. beware this razor is Junk!! The blade does not sit smooth in between the holders. Don't be surprised if you get cut up with it.
  1301. 2+ month ordering time. No tracking # on the package.<br /><br />I'm currently trying to work with the seller to get a refund.<br /><br />While I've been waiting on this razor, I bought a Merkur Futur and while more $, I love the Merkur and I've been shaving with it for months.
  1302. First, the item I ordered is NOT what came. They sent a double edge razor alright but the blade housing is a butterfly mechanism which you might thing is an upgrade however, the entire head of the razor is plastic. I think the handle MIGHT be metal but the rest of the thing is cheap plastic. I guess that's why it was only $2.18. It will make someone a great gag gift at the next gift exchange. Honestly, the plastic box it came in is worth more than the entire shaver.
  1303. I guess its true you get watch you pay for...but its a regular old time razor with a straight blade. How different could it be...well???? it can be really different. The blades are jagged and cut my husband right away. We just threw it and the blades we ordered away.<br />Awful
  1304. not as good as a higher priced one but is ok for the price. be careful with the blades you buy for it
  1305. i chose this rating, because i paid for it, but it never came. This has happened on multiple occasions with multiple items.
  1306. FURTHER UPDATE: It occurred to me that the baseplate of this razor is adjustable because it is made of soft, stamped steel. Therefore, the shaving characteristics of this razor can be tuned. I am experimenting with this, and will be documenting my process and outcome at my blog: shavelikegrandad[dot]blogspot[dot]com. (Substitute periods for the [dot]s.) If this adjustment is successful, this razor may be the best value in DE shaving. For now I've updated my star rating to three based on this adjustment potential. More to come.... UPDATE: I still don't recommend using this razor because the blade exposure is very large, potentially dangerous. However, the handle is heavy and inexpensive. If you prefer a heavy razor with a slightly longer handle than the classic length, this razor may be a good by just for that. Because of the potential benefit of the handle on other razors, I've increased my star rating to two stars, up from one. I bought this Ri,Mei (sic) brand razor (advertised as a Rosallini brand) to see what a razor in the $3-$4 range would be like. One can buy a nice, well functioning razor for $10-$15 -- for example, the Lord L6 or the Weishi 9306-f (see my reviews of both). Physical summary of the Ri,Mei 3-piece razor: Razor is chromed metal in its entirety. Chrome finish has no apparent flaws. The top and handle seem to be cast and machined. The base with safety bars is rigid, stamped steel, thinner than a cast base from a more expensive razor. Handle length is 3-1/2 inches. Razor total weight is 58g. The base plate fits the top well. Without a blade, it looks like a well built razor. The first installation of the provided Chinese blade in the razor demonstrated that the blade doesn't fit snugly onto locating pins in head top. (I would never actually use such a blade near my skin; this initial fitting was just part of my new-razor inspection process.) A higher-quality blade did not fit snugly into the razor either. This sloppy blade seating allows the blade to position unevenly in razor head when assembled. Therefore manual adjustment of blade position is required by eyeballing for even blade exposure as one tightens the handle. This means that a careless user or innocent new DE shaver could install the blade crookedly, which normally would be a hazard. However.... The blade exposure, whether the blade is installed straight or not, is excessive to the point of hazardous. The safety bars on the base plate in no way protect the user from the fully-exposed blade edges. This is a double-edged straight razor masquerading as a safety razor. The finish and fit of the razor itself is good, but once it receives a blade, it becomes unsafe IMHO. An unknowing first-time DE user could try this razor and literally cut his face to shreds. I'm not talking about nicks; I'm talking serious damage. As a test before I attempted to use this razor on my beard, I tried to very carefully shave the hair on my forearm - just to see if this razor was at all usable. Based on that test, it is not usable, and won't go anywhere near my face -- or anyone else's if I can help it. For other shaving-product reviews and general information, Internet search ShaveLikeGrandad (in other words, that's ShaveLikeGrandad[dot]blogspot[dot]com).
  1307. The head is very flimsy and the blades do not seat correctly to provide a good cut, not to mention it takes like 15 or more days to come from China. I do not recommend this product.
  1308. I'll keep this very simple. You get EXACTLY what you pay for with this product. Nothing more, nothing less. You're buying a $4 razor. It's plastic. Don't expect anything spectacular. For a $4 razor it gets 5 stars. For a razor in general it gets 1. I'd buy it as a prop for a costume or a collectors piece, but not a working razor.

I may take a week or so for your face to adjust to the new razor (if your converting from the traditional saftey razor-Mach 3), But a good purchase.
  1310. The razor head has to be disassembled to change the blade. Other similar razors open on top to allow blade cleaning and changing. Works OK.
  1311. Figured I'd try a cheapo razor of this type after seeing the bald guy pitching his razor on tv. I hate my 3 blade, expensive cartridge razor and wanted to see if this type of shaving was viable. Wasn't expecting much from this for the price. BOOM. This thing is amazing! Used with the persona blades, this is THE way to shave. My brother loved it too and ordered the Mehaz. I tried it- and stayed with this &#34;cheapo&#34; razor. Also, with the money saved on this, get a shaving brush, bowl, and a tin of Synergy shaving soap and shave like a real man. I got a second one in case I lose my first one. At this price you have nothing to lose. Note this is a little aggressive, but if you don't push you get a great shave without getting cut at all.

  1400. I picked this up when I decided to try switching to a safety razor (for monetary reasons). I quickly fell in love with the shave I got from using a safety razor. I've since switched this razor into my travel kit as I use a 1960s gillette that was given to me daily now. If you're interested in trying a safety razor you can't go wrong here.<br /><br />4 stars instead of 5 because the decorate end piece of the razor screws in and somehow became stripped very easily. The razor still works great, but it's not quite as nice looking anymore.
  1401. Held the blade so far out I would have slit my throat. I threw it away.
  1402. DO NOT ATTEMPT TO SHAVE W/ THE BLADE THAT ARRIVES W/ THE RAZOR.......YOU WILL BLEED. W/ A NEW BLADE (AQUIRED SEPARATELY)....GOOD.
  1403. I purchased this just to get a feeling of the safety blades that go with it. I have been very pleasantly surprised at how well the safety blades work compared to the electric razor I had previously used. I thought I would purchase a more expensive shaver, but I have continued using this shaver without any issues. I may upgrade someday, but for now, I don't have a reason to.
  1404. The razor itself has a good heft to it, which helps with control when shaving. I did not know, however, that it unscrews in three parts to change the blade; the shaft, cover, and base, It took a bit to get the hang of how to put the blade in, and put it back together without cutting myself. I recommend holding it on the ends, or carefully below the lower guard. It's a great shaver, though, and I'm as happy with the results as I ever was with those multi-blade razors.
  1405. This all-metal double edge safety razor is manufactured in China by RiMei, a company which also produces knives and nail clippers, among other items. It's taken a beating from China bashing reviewers here, somewhat unfairly. This is NOT, a poorly made or engineered piece of junk. It shaves very well, as good as any 3 or 5 blade on the market. I used the RiMei blade which comes with the razor, for my first half dozen shaves. Very good performance from both razor and blade. Blade was held securely and in good alignment by the razor's three-piece construction. This is not a butterfly mechanism razor, but a three piece. Many expensive razors are three piece design. Changing blades is neither dangerous, nor cumbersome, as some have suggested. The handle is all-metal (not plastic as noted in Amazon's description) and measures 3.5 inches. It's lightweight at 1.6 ounces. The heavyweight models of the high priced brands weigh in at twice that. A Gillette Fusion Pro Glide (manual) is 1.4 ounces. I purchased this RiMei razor at Amazon for $6, together with 50 Derby blades for $5. That's easily more than a year's worth of shaves for me. BTW, I use Barbasol shaving cream at a buck a can. I'm not a 'wet shaving' snob. This inexpensive razor gives me a good, forgiving shave. Perhaps a pricier razor - Parker (India), Merkur (Germany), Feather (Japan) or Jagger (England) is in my future. I could be drawn to an extra half inch on the handle and a heftier overall weight. 4.5 stars.<br /><br />Added thoughts: I've been using the razor for a few weeks. Still delighted with it. In fact, when I noticed it was available on Amazon for $3.48 from Hong Kong, I ordered another. Might give it to my son-in-law. I use it with Derby blades and have nothing but good things to say about that combination. It's light, but I'm now thinking that may be of benefit, allowing the shaver and not the razor to apply proper pressure. I purchased a badger brush, but still use my cheap Barbasol. I get a very good shave, seconds, not minutes longer than with my former Mach. And, I have a Mercur long handled 180 razor on my Amazon wishlist, but for now I'm very satisfied with this product. I give it 5 stars.
  1406. Definitely has the heft and weight I expected from an old-school razor. However, there are a lot of moving parts; the handle screws into the head, the base of the handle is attached by a bolt of some kind. Works well so far, just seems to have a lot of moving parts, which I wasn't expecting.

  1440. Frankly, I would be thrilled with this purchase at 5x the price. The build quality is amazing. It's forgiving for those new to shaving with a double edged razor. I also couldn't find a good way to properly balance close shaves and a lack of irritation.<br /><br />My cost per week is now down to about 30¢. (A 90% reduction in price!)<br /><br />My shaves are now very close without irritating my face or neck.<br /><br />One thing I have definitely noticed is how dependent this system is on a proper blade. I have problems shaving my neck, as I am skinny and my adam's apple really sticks out, but I have been able to deliver a smooth shave without any irritation at all.   1459. When I recently decided to give safety razors another shot after several years of living with a beard, I was looking to ease back into the process with an inexpensive product. To be honest, I didn't have the highest expectations given the price point, but I was very pleasantly surprised. This razor is a good size and feels very comfortable and solid in my hand. It has just enough weight to give the blade good contact with my skin without the need to apply additional pressure (a real failing of multiple blade modern razors that leads to irritation and cuts). The safety guard appears and feels to have an appropriate length and orientation, and the fittings definitely produce the proper angle on the blade itself to give a nice, close shave. After nearly a month of using the razor, I've not cut or irritated myself once. Shaving has become a pleasure again thanks in large part to this inexpensive, but quality razor.
  1460.   1464. This product has gotten a lot of reviews but, since I am apparently now on a razor collecting kick so let me throw another one into the pot. My review, of course, will include tips and possibly historical notes but feel free to correct anything I write.<br /><br />The only downside of this product was that it took awhile to get here. When it did come, I had to sign for it, and it came in a padded envelope nicely sealed.<br /><br />This razor does appear to be all metal and it comes with one double edge blade. It is quite similar to the first razor issued to U.S. troops in World War I when being clean shaving was supposedly a requirement do to the advent of gas masks.<br /><br />Way back, one of the razor companies issued a replica of the first military issue razor, I believe, in order to mark the anniversary of that event--fiftieth anniversary I imagine which would make it 1968. That razor was three parts: the two part head that sandwiched in the blade and the handle that screwed into the bolt part sticking down through the blade and the bottom of the head from the top part of the head. Basically, you just unscrewed the head, opened it, changed the blade, closed it, and screwed the handle back on. Simplo, no?<br /><br />Also vary good. After trying the razor I bought back then I started having a lot of suspicions that the so-called \\"butterfly\\" opening mechanism on a double edge blade was perhaps a convenience of sorts but did not improve the way the razor shaved. There was a dial adjustable double edge back that which could be even worse if you cranked it up too high.<br /><br />This razor is actually four parts since the handle has a metal end cap that screws on. This knob looks like it adjusts something but it just finishes the handle. Inside is a hollow tube in which you could secrete your illegal drugs to avoid being hung in Malaysia or whatever they do when they catch you with illegal drugs nowadays.<br /><br />Anyway--the head is magnetic, the handles seems to be plated brass. The whole thing comes on a rather unsecure store display card and there is a wrapped blade inside the cover of the card. The blade seems rather thin but it did an excellet shave. The card itself is mostly printed with Asian characters.<br /><br />I imagine, in Asia or in the third world, this is probably just a common drugstore or five and dime or variety store type item and sells for a few dollars.<br /><br />Now the real review: It shaves well with the blade supplied. The one I received seems to be all metal and it looks nice. It seems well made and sturdy and would probably last you your entire shaving career if you took care of it. In poorer lands this is probably a big sales incentive.<br /><br />I reviewed a fifteen dollar double edge razor a few days ago and I prefer this razor hands down. This razor had the proper weight and feel to it and the handle is nice and long compared to my dad's old Gillette from the seventies.<br /><br />If the product delivered is consistent and identical to the razors (yes, I ordered two at that price) that I got then they are well worth the money and the wait for delivery.<br /><br />Happy shaving. Stan. I nearly forgot a shaving tip: don't shave before you wash your face with soap and hot water until your beard softens. I worked in the Baptist Hospital psychiatric facility here in town during my fabulous second career as a boy secretary and the only one in the place half the time who could unscrew their computers without calling IS for help. In this position I often volunteered to watch our male patients shave (they do this to avoid just handing out razor blades to psychotics and the suicidally depressed--go figure). During all that time I only saw two guys who knew how to shave properly and get a good shave. One of these was a self styled devil worshiper in an immature and silly sort of way. As in interesting side note: the Satanic Bible he was allowed to keep in our age of tolerancewas actually a big coffee table book well illustrated and quite interesting. The average shaving 'technique' among a lot of people seems to be to just put foam from a can on your beard and have ho.<br /><br />So--wash your face and soften your beard and don't blame the devil if your face is raw. Again, please note, that turning a double edge razor on your face is a no no. It is the edge that can nick you unless you run over a bump or bug bite.<br /><br />God Bless.

I use this to shave my legs and it works perfectly. However, I do suggest watching videos on how to use a double edged blade razor. There are some instructions telling you not to apply pressure because you could peel your skin off.

  1468. This was a gift, so I can NOT review! Besides I have A full beard.
  1469. Takes some getting used to, because the blades are shaaarp! But the pro is a hundred blades for $7...., Wow! Ever priced triple blades or quad blades.. Outrageous! I would recommend to anyone looking to save a lot of money by going old school..
  1470. I remember my Dad shaving with an old fashioned double edge razor, but I never tried it myself. When I got wind of how good a shave with such a razor could be I did some online research and came up with this inexpensive razor. People generally liked it, so I gave it a try.<br />The razor seems to be well made and of moderate weight. I'd like a slightly longer handle, but I've only shaved with it 4 times, and I may well get used to this one. I find shaving in this way takes a bit more time than an electric or an expensive cartridge type razor, but the shave is fantastic. In a pinch, I can get away with not shaving the next day.<br />My only real quibble with the razor is that you have to take the whole top off to change blades which is awkward and potentially dangerous, as you have to fumble out with several pieces including a very sharp blade. This razor comes with only one blade, so I've ordered more. If I stick with DE shaving, I might look into a &#34;butterfly&#34; style razor for daily use, and keep this one for travel where it's short length could be a benefit.

  1481. When the razor arrived it had slightly sharp corners to the safety bar and on one side the bar was slightly bent. A few light strokes with a sanding block against the corners and gentle bending back into place with a pair of pliers, this is a decent product. I have always had trouble with shaving. The disposable razors and multi blade cartridge razors alike give me ingrown hairs, razor burn, cuts, and a lousy shave. Electric razors were ok, but really only chopped it down a bit for every day appearances, but the neck hair was never very well cut. This is my first DE razor, and this morning I used it for the second time. The shave is possibly the best I have ever had. It is going to take a while to learn to use it like a pro, but I am sold on the notion of DE razors. I do wonder what the more expensive ones offer for the price, but for a first time buyer on a budget, I definitely recommend this one. Just for further information, having heard conflicting things about the razor the comes with it, I opted to use an Astra Superior Platinum blade that I had ordered.

  1485. I bought one these a few weeks ago and I liked it so much I ordered two more for spares.<br />These are three piece razors that are all metal and no plastics.<br />This razor shaves really well with different types of blades.
  1486. I bought this as insurance against Gillette pulling their best blade of all time, the original Sensor blade off the market. It is already impossible to find the generic blades and the Sensor blades are now selling for about $23 for a ten-pack. I found them online for less than half the price. Meanwhile, this Silver Tone Double Edge Razor took nearly on month to arrive (from China, believe it or not), but since I was in no hurry, this was not a problem. Upon receiving it, I used it along with a Derby Extra blade and, I received a comfortable, close shave, throwing me back some 30 years when I strictly used my Hoffritz safety razor (German - can't find them now) which broke after many years of service upon dropping it. For comparison, before ordering the Silver Tone, I borrowed my son's Merkur razor with a Feather blade, which for my needs gave me a disappointing shave after trying every conceivable angle. Without getting too technical, my Silver Tone and Derby Extra blade, gave me three close shaves shaving every other day, while the fourth shave was not as good, but about the same as my son's Merkur/Feather combination on my first and only shave with it. For anyone considering going to the double edge safety razor, I would highly recommend giving this one a try before going for the expensive ones. For $3.50 and no tax or shipping, it's a no-brainer. Its weight and long handle are perfect for me, although you may want to try another blade that suits your needs. As a point of reference: I have sensitive skin in the neck area and a pretty stubborn grey beard.

I think the vendor did a great job as it shipped quickly and my disappointment was my own fault as the product is not misrepresented.

  1523. I wanted to switch from an electric, so I bought this to complete my DE starter set:<br /><br />- This razor<br />- [[ASIN:B001A3HPT0 Van Der Hagen Premium Shave Set (Soap, Bowl, Brush)]] (boar brush, bowl, shave soap)<br />- [[ASIN:B001G5FOLI 10 Feather Razor Blades NEW Hi-stainless Double Edge]]<br />- [[ASIN:B000UVQ3V4 The Real Shaving Co. Post Shave Soothing Balm, Moisturising, 4.23 oz.]]<br /><br />This razor works fine. The handle could be better and maybe heavier, but it works. It might be possible to fill the hollow handle with soemthing to add heft. There is a little slop in the blade, so just make sure it's symmetrical to the combs before tightening up. I skipped the included blade and went right to the Feathers.<br /><br />Other reviewers said the ball end easily comes loose, but mine hasn't. Superglue on the threads would fix that anyway.<br /><br />I wanted an inexpensive start to try DE shaving. This razor came through, and at this price I was able to get my whole setup for less than the price of a typical Merkur. I'll probably upgrade at some point, but no rush... this works fine.<br /><br />Some tips from my early experience:<br />- Use a very light touch, and multiple passes.<br />- The RS Soothing Balm feels and smells great, and works wonders on that bloody rash you get if you forget and try to use pressure. It heals it up almost as if it didn't happen.<br />- A DE shave the night before is better than an electric shave in the morning.
  1524. When I was younger, my dad gave me a double edge razor. It was a good razor and I liked it. But then Gillette sent me a free sample over the mail, and I got hooked on the triple, quad, and five blade type uhmm or better yet hype. But like many here, I realized that the replacements kept getting costlier and costlier (and the specials kept getting fewer and less in between). I am a frugal guy and I would stretch out the use of my cartridges. But at the cost of getting in-grown hairs quite often.<br /><br />I received my razor today and like many here, I had buyers reservations; after all I purchased one of the cheaper versions available. I will say it does not have cheap feel. One thing that popped up at me is the following that appears on the packaging...<br /><br />{\\"We were certified ISO90001 in 2003 and strict quality control systems has been implemented to guarantee our product with excellent quality. Our products, rich in variety and novel in pattern, are warmly welcomed by consumers.\\" \\"...Highly advanced techniques are adopted in the product design, mould facture, heat treatment, polishing and electroplating, so that each technical target of our product is above the standards of light industry newly issues.\\"}<br /><br />After feeling the razor in my hand, I was highly impressed. I did not get the impression that I had just squandered my money - my biggest reservation. Hence I quickly set up the razor with the blade it came with. And shaved as normal. And I got a very good quality shave in my opinion. Even my wife mentioned to me that somehow the razor made my face look more youthful. And I've been shaving every day with Gillette Fusion or Mach 3 type razors for years. I am not a guy who walks around with a beard or mustache. So, it wasn't the fact I was clean shaven. But it did even out those little bumps created by in-grown hairs.<br /><br />One thing though, for you who are in my situation. This is a razor that will even out the ingrown hair bumps. Therefore, when you first start using it, it will likely result in some light bleeding. The Gillett Fusion or Mach 3 would only shave above the skin.<br /><br />Also for some of you who may have reservation that this razor handle isn't 5 inches long (lenght), I say don't worry about that. I have normal sized hands. I've been to the Hollywood walk of fame, and my hands are pretty normal. Same size as Jack Nicholson and Johnny Depp (I measured them in the cement moldings). The razor does not feel small at all. With the metal weight, it feels perfect and heavy duty in my grip.<br /><br />I was both hesitant and excited to look in the Double Edge razor market again. My first impressions are that I got a really good deal. But I'll post anything regarding the quality if I experience anything negative.<br /><br />FYI, I am reintroducing myself to Double Edge razors again. Hence I am not an expert, and will not have any knowledge regarding the higher end razors. I know that it was a tough decision, potentially squander 7 bucks on this razor or just go with a quality reputable $30 dollar razor. I gambled!!! And I'm initially highly satisfied. I don't foresee requiring top of the line just yet.<br /><br />Update: I've been using this razor for about a year, and I can say that I am beyond pleased. Gone are the ingrown hairs on my neck, which used to always give me little pimples on my neck (nothing too terribly bad, but somewhat of an annoyance). I originally got this razor at $7 dollars, and I bought a replacement to put in the drawer for $3.5, and now I see they are $2.61.... Geesh what a bargain... I am aware the economy picked up and there is more money in the pocket for most folks, but this is a good quality razor. Would never go back to expensive disposable razors that cost an arm and a leg. One more bit of info, I do use shaving cream which extends the life of the blade, and continues to give a comfortable shave - once I feel the slightest pull, I without hesitation replace the blade :) I got 100 blades for 7 bucks on Amazon --- can't beat that.

  1527. I bought this razor handle to get back into safety razor, cheap-blade shaving.<br /><br />I used to have a very high quality Merkur razor but it was stolen with my luggage a few years ago. I have been using some silly Gillette Mach 3 Turbo Ultra Quattro Mega does-your-taxes razor for a while. I bought this to try out safety razor shaving and see if I wanted to go back.<br /><br />I forgot how great a safety razor shave can be. It is not a chore anymore. I actually look forward to shaving now. It takes a bit longer to do it properly with a badger hair brush, real shaving soap and a safety razor, but the results are way better especially if you have tough whiskers and sensitive skin like me.<br /><br />This is a reasonable quality handle and comes with one blade. The blade is low quality but good blades are much less than $1 each when bought in quantity.<br /><br />Buy this razor, read up on tips and technique, turn shaving from a chore into something you look forward to.

  1533. I gives a great shave, in fact, the closest, and smoothest shave I've ever had--even with a beard going (with other shavers it's impossible, often). However, it's got some minor faults. Ok. lets break it down.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1- great close shave<br />2- adjustable for length (most contemporary makes aren't so much)--pretty versatile<br />3-replaceable blades you can buy at lots of places, compared to specific maker/model replacing<br />4-cheap (why else would you be reading this?)<br /><br />Cons:<br />1- with the closeness of the shave, it's also quite a tricky instrument--I got nicked several times using it today (got it in the mail)--and I guess it's because I'm used to more modern razors. (I expected the metal to be a bit more sturdy and ample feeling in my hands--but its made from cheap metal, not like the old ones probably were made)<br />--also, be careful about the bottom adjustment nob...I was tinkering with mine and it fell down the drain :[<br />but crap, it still works. now that I mention this...<br />3- the adjustment nobs/toggles don't stay &#34;stuck&#34; for too long, you have to adjust it several times during use, well, pending what you're doing. Because, you might decide to stick with contemporary razors, after all. Feel me?<br /><br />paix

  1545. This is a good little razor. It is a 3 piece double edge (DE) razor and is easy to assemble. It is very light weight and that is not a bad thing because it allows you to control the razor better. It is a great starter razor for beginners. I have used it for quite some time now and I am impressed with its performance. At first I was worried that it would not work as well as my Edwin Jagger and Merkur razors, but once I began shaving I was shocked on how well it was cutting my whiskers. It is a smooth shaver and is easy to clean. I no longer get razor burn or cuts thanks to this little tool. This was one of my first safety razors and I got plenty of practice with this model. My wife uses it on her legs and she also says it is awesome so it is good for the ladies too. Another plus to this razor is that DE blades are extremely cheap! You no longer need to spend tons of money on those useless cartridges that give you ingrown hairs. Ouch! Anyways, I give this razor a 4 star rating only because it is not as elegant as my Edwin Jagger, but it certainly gets the job done and the price makes it a winner. I definitely recommend it.

  1549. For $3 I can't ask for more, and that's why I am giving it four stars. I have a Merkur 180, and comparing the I like my Merkur but it's also 10x the cost.<br /><br />If you buy this, I recommend getting some sharp blades because it's not very heavy and you can't depend just on the weight of the razor. If this is your first DE its perfect because you can learn your technique with it.<br /><br />If this is your second DE like me (my primary is a Merkur 180), be careful. I had a lot of trouble at first to adjust to it because I wanted to use more pressure to offset the lightness. Plus my first one has a longer handle so I was having trouble with my grip.<br /><br />In conclusion, for $3 its not bad. For someone on the fence about wet shaving or someone needing a second razor and not able to spend much money on it. Also for those on the fence about getting something nicer, I would not recommend keeping this forever as my main razor so if you want spend the money on something nicer now.
